questions.text: Identify the type of inhibition from the given graph
questions.solution:
Enzyme inhibition

Selective inhibition of a particular enzyme is a common mode of drug action. Such inhibition is either competitive or noncompetitive.

(i) Competitive (equilibrium type) The drug being structurally similar competes with the normal substrate for the catalytic binding site of the enzyme so that the product is not formed or a nonfunctional product is formed. Such inhibitors increase the kM but the Vmax remains unchanged

A nonequilibrium type of enzyme inhibition can also occur with drugs which react with the same catalytic site of the enzyme but either form strong covalent bonds or have such high affinity for the enzyme that the normal substrate is not able to displace the inhibitor, e.g.

  • Organophosphates react covalently with the esteratic site of the enzyme cholinesterase.

In these situations, kM is increased and Vmax is reduced.

(ii) Noncompetitive The inhibitor reacts with an adjacent site and not with the catalytic site, but alters the enzyme in such a way that it loses its catalytic property. Thus, kM is unchanged but Vmax is reduced.

Reference: K D Tripathi 8th edition page 47

questions.text: A patient presented with general fatigue and tiredness. Primary clinical examination is uneventful. Lab studies showed Normal TLC & DLC. No immature cells were seen. Superficial discrete lymph nodes were enlarged. Biopsy showed effaced architecture, indented nucleus, prominent nucleolus containing atypical cells. CD10 and BCL2 positive. What could be the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Greater than 85% of follicular lymphomas have a characteristic (14;18) translocation that fuses the BCL2 gene on chromosome 18 to the IgH locus on chromosome 14.
  • This chromosomal rearrangement results in the inappropriate "overexpression" of BCL2 protein, which you will recall is an inhibitor of apoptosis that contributes to cell survival.
  • Lymph nodes usually are effaced by a distinctly nodular proliferation (Fig.).
  • Most commonly, the predominant neoplastic cells are so-called "centrocytes' ', cells slightly larger than resting lymphocytes that have angular "cleaved" nuclei with prominent indentations and linear infoldings (Fig.).
  • The nuclear chromatin is coarse and condensed, and nucleoli are indistinct.
  • These centrocytes are mixed with variable numbers of centroblasts, larger cells with vesicular chromatin, several nucleoli, and modest amounts of cytoplasm.
  • In most tumors, centroblasts are a minor component of the overall cellularity, mitoses are infrequent, and single necrotic cells (cells undergoing apoptosis) are not seen.
  • These features help to distinguish follicular lymphoma from follicular hyperplasia, in which mitosis and apoptosis are prominent. Uncommonly, large cells predominate, a histologic pattern that correlates with a more aggressive clinical behavior.

Immunophenotype. These tumors express B cell markers such as CD20 and the germinal center B cell markers CD10 and BCL6; of note, BCL6 is a transcription factor that is required for the generation of germinal center B cells.


Clinical Features. Follicular lymphoma mainly occurs in adults older than 50 years of age and affects males and females equally. It usually manifests as painless, generalized lymphadenopathy. The bone marrow is involved at diagnosis in approximately 80% of cases.

Follicular lymphoma-lymph node. (A) Nodular aggregates of lymphoma cells are present throughout. (B) At high magnification, small lymphoid cells with condensed chromatin and irregular or cleaved nuclear outlines (centrocytes) are mixed with a population of larger cells with nucleoli (centroblasts).

Reference: Robbins basic pathology, 10th ed, Page- 469

questions.text: A 30 year old male presents to the clinic with a irregular Painless ulcer that he noticed 2 weeks ago. On examination, the ulcer is non tender and regional lymphadenopathy is noted. He admits of having a unprotected sex with a new partner. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• The case history points towards syphilis.
  • Syphilis is a bacterial infection caused by the spirochete Treponema pallidum.
  • pallidum is the only treponemal agent that causes venereal disease.
  • Primary syphilis appears 10 to 90 days after exposure to the infection and comprises a painless, indurated ulcer (chancre) at the site of inoculation with the pallidum.
  • The chancre oozes serum, which is teeming with treponema
  • Regional lymphadenopathy - bilateral, painless rubbery inguinal lymph nodes enlargement.
  • In this case next best step, would be to do dark field microscopy
  • Darkfield examination by microscope allows for direct examination of spirochetes from the mucosal lesion and thus offers an immediate diagnosis if positive, corkscrew motility seen
  • Test to rule out other STI should be done if feasible .
  • Inj Benzathine penicillin 2.4 mIU is the treatment of choice

REFERENCE :Rooks textbook of dermatology , chapter 29, page 29.22

questions.text: True statement about thymoma is
questions.solution:
Mediastinum division

Middle mediastinum contains heart, anterior mediastinum is present behind the sternum, posterior mediastinum is anterior to the vertebra.

Mases found in corresponding mediastinum:

Anterior mediastinum- thymoma (most common tumour), lymphoma, GERM cell tumors

Superior mediastinum- extension of thyroid, parathyroid, lymphomas

Posterior mediastinum- the common tumors seen here are neurogenic tumours(MC), lymphoma, oesophageal tumors

Middle mediastinum- bronchogenic cyst, cardiac tumours

Thymoma is an important gland that becomes rudimentary as we grow, but can develop into the most common neoplasm of thymoma. It does not cause dysphagia. It is not seen on X Ray. CT scan is used to diagnose. Thymoma can produce myasthenia like symptoms.

Classification of Thymoma- Masoaka Staging of thymoma.

questions.text: A patient presented with bitemporal hemianopia. On imaging it is found that an artery aneurysm is pressing on optic chiasm. What is the likely artery involved?
questions.solution: At the optic chiasm, the nasal fibres of the optic nerve decussate. These crossed fibres are more damaged than the uncrossed fibres. This leads to bitemporal hemianopia. The structures that are close to the optic chiasm include the anterior communicating artery and the pituitary stalk. Aneurysms of the anterior communicating artery or mass lesions of the sella cause this visual field defect.

questions.text: A sample is taken from the perineal area of 10 year old rape victim. A test was performed using picric acid that showed yellow needle shaped crystal. What is the test?
questions.solution:
Barberio's Test: A saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid when added to spermatic fluid produces yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate. The reaction depends on the presence of prostatic secretion.

OTHER TESTS FOR SPERM DETECTION

Florence Test: The stain is extracted by 10% hydrochloric acid, and a drop is placed on a glass slide and allowed to dry. A coverslip is placed over this, and a drop of Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water) is allowed to run under the coverslip. If semen is present, dark-brown crystals of choline iodide appear immediately. Choline originates from the seminal vesicles. The test is not proof of seminal fluid, but only of presence of some vegetable or animal substance. A negative reaction is proof that the stain is not seminal.

Acid Phosphatase Test: The prostatic secretion element of seminal fluid contains 500 to 1000 times greater acid phosphatase than any other body fluid. Undiluted semen has an acid phosphatase activity of 340 to 360 Bodansky units or 2500 to 3500 Angstrom units per ml. The concentration of acid phosphatase gradually falls with time in vaginal secretions, and positive reactions are found for periods of 36 hours, with gradual disappearance in 72 hours. Concentration in excess of hundred Bodansky units with or without motile sperms indicate that ejaculation occurred within twelve hours of examination. Dried seminal stains which have not undergone putrefaction retain acid phosphatase activity for weeks or months. This test is conclusive in the absence of demonstrable sperms or in aspermia.

Creatine Phosphokinase: Spermatozoa contain a high concentration of creatine phosphokinase. Normal seminal fluid contains 385 to 1400 units of CPK/ml. Levels over 400 are almost diagnostic of seminal stains. The enzyme is stable and can be demonstrated even in old stains of six months.

Immunological Method: MHS-5 produced from seminal vesicles and Mab 4 E6 can be detected on the sperm cells and in the ejaculated fluid. Prostate specific antigen (PSA, P30) is a glycoprotein produced by prostate and is found in seminal plasma (normal and aspermic semen), male urine and blood, but not in any tissues or fluid of the female. It is found in vaginal fluid up to 27 hours after sexual intercourse. Tests for P 30 have replaced the quantitative analysis for acid phosphatase. A positive PSA finding is a reliable indicator of semen, regardless of the presence of spermatozoa or elevated acid phosphatase level.

Fluorescent in situ hybridisation (FISH) has been suggested as a sensitive and specific test for detection of male epithelial cells in the post-coital vagina up to one week. Y -chromosome positive epithelial cells have Sexual Offences 435 been identified in vaginal swabs even in cases with no ejaculation.

Choline and Spermine Test: Liquid semen and dried seminal stains can be identified by a thin layer chromatographic technique. The test is based on the unique combination of choline and spermine which is present only in semen. Spermine is found in testes, pancreas, liver, spleen, brain, blood, bone marrow and body fluids, but its concentration is lower than in semen. One microliter of semen present can be detected by this method. The sensitivity of detection and identification has been enormously enhanced by amplification techniques, such as PCR (polymerase chain reaction). Y chromosome short tandem repeat (STR) markers have been successfully used to analyse mixed stains with a male component. After vasectomy, chemical and enzymatic tests for semen remain positive, though no sperms will be present.

TESTS FOR BLOOD

Takayama test (Haemochromogen crystal test):

  • Used to detect: Bloodstains
  • Stain used: Takayama reagent (sodium hydroxide. pyridine, glucose)
  • Finding: If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen or reduced alkaline haematin appear in a few minutes

Teichmann's test (Haemin crystal Test):

  • Used to detect: Bloodstains.
  • Stain used: Glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride.

Finding: If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of haemin or haematin chloride appear


Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, K S Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 337

questions.text: A 24-year-old female presents with 36 w+6 days gestation. On examination, fetus was transverse lie with adequate liquor, placenta in normal position. Weight of the baby is 2.8 kg. What is the ideal management?
questions.solution:
External cephalic version, or "ECV", is a procedure to try to turn a baby around while they are still in the uterus.

  • Indication: Singleton pregnancy with breech/transverse lie
  • Uterine relaxant (terbutaline) is given.
  • If successful: Induction of labour
  • If attempt fails: Schedule a C-section at 39 weeks.
  • If fetal distress or bradycardia occurs during ECV:
  1. Stop procedure
  2. Revert fetus to its normal position
  3. Emergency C-section

questions.text: Duct of Bellini are present in?
questions.solution:
• Uriniferous tubules:
  • From a functional point of view the kidney may be regarded as a collection of numerous uriniferous tubules that are specialised for the excretion of urine.
  • Each uriniferous tubule consists of an excretory part called the nephron, and of a collecting tubule.
  • The collecting tubules draining different nephrons join to form larger tubules called the papillary ducts (of Bellini), each of which opens into a minor calyx at the apex of a renal papilla.
  • Each kidney contains one to two million nephrons.

Reference: Textbook of Histology by I. B. Singh, 9th Edition, Page No - 225

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presented with swelling in forearm. Radiograph is given below. What is the Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Giant cell tumors of bone, also known as osteoclastomas, are relatively common bone tumors and are usually benign. They typically arise from the metaphysis of long bones, extend into the epiphysis adjacent to the joint surface, and have a narrow zone of transition.

General radiographic features include:

  • A narrow zone of transition: a broader zone of transition is seen in more aggressive giant cell tumors o no surrounding sclerosis: 80-85%
  • Overlying cortex is thinned, expanded, or deficient
  • Periosteal reaction is only seen in 10-30% of cases
  • Soft tissue mass is not infrequent
  • A pathological fracture may be present
  • No matrix calcification/mineralization

Reference: AIIMS-MAMC-PAGEI's Comprehensive textbook of diagnostic radiology page no 1435

questions.text: Breast biopsy shows the following histopathological image. The tumor cells show PAS positivity. What is your most likely diagnosis
questions.solution:
• There are clefts in the epidermal layers containing large tumour cells
  • Paget's disease of the nipple is an eczematoid lesion of the nipple, often associated with an invasive or non-invasive ductal carcinoma of the underlying breast. The nipple bears a crusted, scaly and eczematoid lesion with a palpable subareolar mass in about half the cases. Most of the patients with palpable mass are found to have infiltrating duct carcinoma, while those with no palpable breast lump are usually subsequently found to have intraductal carcinoma.
  • The pathogenesis of Paget's disease of the breast is explained by the following 2 hypotheses:
    1. The tumour cells from the underlying ductal carcinoma have migrated up into the lactiferous ducts and invaded the epidermis producing skin lesions.
    2. An alternate theory, though less reliable than the former, is that Paget's disease represents a form of carcinoma in situ of the epidermis itself.
  • MORPHOLOGIC FEATURES Grossly, the skin of the nipple and areola is crusted, fissured and ulcerated with oozing of serosanguineous fluid from the erosions.
  • Histologically, the skin lesion is characterised by the presence of Paget's cells singly or in small clusters in the epidermis. These cells are larger than the epidermal cells, spherical, having hyperchromatic nuclei with cytoplasmic halo that stains positively with mucicarmine. In these respects, Paget's cells are adenocarcinoma-type cells. In addition, the underlying breast contains invasive or non-invasive duct carcinoma which shows no obvious direct invasion of the skin of nipple.

Reference: Harshmohan textbook of pathology, 7th edition, Page- 756

Onodi cells and haller cells of ethmoid are related respectively to:
questions.solution:
Ethmoidal air cells have been given specific names, because of their importance in surgical procedures or involvement in head and neck pathologies:

  • Frontal recess cells, including the agger nasi cells
  • Ethmoid bulla
  • Haller cells
  • Onodi cells

Frontal recess cells are anterior ethmoid air cells that pneumatize the frontal recess.

Agger nasi air cells are the most anterior ethmoidal air cells lying anterolateral and inferior to the frontal recess and anterior and above the attachment of the middle turbinate.

The ethmoid bulla, also known as bulla ethmoidalis, is the largest and most consistent air cell of the anterior ethmoid air cells.

Haller cells, also known as infraorbital ethmoidal air cells, are ethmoid air cells located lateral to the maxillo-ethmoidal suture along the inferomedial orbital floor.

Sphenoethmoidal air cell, also commonly known as the Onodi air cell, is an anatomical variant of the paranasal sinuses, important due to its close proximity to the optic nerve and internal carotid artery.

questions.text: In MSUD (maple syrup urine disorder) which of the following is not restricted:
questions.solution:
• MSUD (maple syrup urine disorder) is a Metabolic disorder of branched-chain amino acid catabolism.
  • As the name implies, the odor of urine in maple syrup urine disease (branched-chain ketonuria, or MSUD) suggests maple syrup, or burnt sugar.
  • The biochemical defect in MSUD involves the α-keto acid decarboxylase complex.
  • Plasma and urinary levels of leucine, isoleucine, valine, and their α-keto acids and α-hydroxy acids (reduced α-keto acids) are elevated, but the urinary keto acids derived principally from leucine.
  • Signs and symptoms of MSUD often include fatal ketoacidosis, neurological derangements, mental retardation, and a maple syrup odor of urine. The mechanism of toxicity is unknown.
  • Early diagnosis by enzymatic analysis is essential to avoid brain damage and early mortality by replacing dietary protein by an amino acid mixture that lacks leucine, isoleucine, and valine.
  • Option B, Option C & Option D: valine, leucine & isoleucine are branched chain amino acids, which are restricted.
  • Option A: Methionine is sulphur containing amino acids, and should not be restricted in MSUD.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, Chapter 29, Page 290

questions.text: A 13 years old boy presented with patchy depigmented skin along with leukotrichia in segmental distribution. The depigmentation started 1 year back but has been static for the last 4 months. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Segmental vitiligo is a subtype of vitiligo.
  • progressive development of circumscribed depigmented macules or patches in a segmental pattern over a period of 6-24 months, followed by rapid spontaneous stabilization.
  • Segmental vitiligo typically involves a single segment (monosegmental) on only one side of the bod, unilateral distribution, do not cross the midline
  • It typically has an earlier age of onset compared with generalized vitiligo.
  • There is a higher frequency of leukotrichia (white hair) compared to nonsegmental vitiligo.
  • Topical steroids are not very effective
  • Surgical managements yields good results

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 88, page 88.37

Piebaldism:

  • Autosomal dominant disease
  • Defect: KIT gene mutation
  • Clinically patient present with white triangular or rhomboid patch of depigmentation in frontal, median scalp with white forelock of hair since birth.

Nevus anemicus

  • Nevus anemicus is an uncommon, congenital vascular malformation resulting in hypopigmented cutaneous macules and/or patches. Nevus anemicus is attributed to the increased sensitivity of cutaneous blood vessels to catecholamines such as epinephrine (adrenaline) and norepinephrine (noradrenaline). This hypersensitivity results in permanent vasoconstriction leading to hypopigmentation.

Reference: Bolognia textbook of dermatology, 4th edition.

questions.text: Nivolumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor approved for
questions.solution:
Immune checkpoint inhibitors: James P. Allison and Tasuku Honjo received Nobel prize in physiology or medicine for their discovery of cancer therapy by inhibition of negative immune regulation.

Normally, there are certain checkpoints, so that immune cells (like T-cells) do not attack self antigens. Certain receptors like PD-1 (programmed death receptors) or CTLA-4 (cytotoxic T-lymphocyte associated protein) are present on T-cells. When ligands on other cells (PDL-1 or CD-80/86 respectively) bind to these receptors, T-cells are inhibited. Same method is utilized by some cancer cells to evade destruction from T-cells.

These tumor cells overexpress the ligands like PDL-1 and inhibit T-cells. Monoclonal antibodies targeting these interactions result in disinhibition of these brakes and thus, T-cells can destroy cancer cells.

  1. PD-1 and PDL-1 inhibitors
    • Nivolumab, Pembrolizumab and Cemiplimab are monoclonal antibodies against PD-1 receptors on T-cells.
    • Atezolizumab, Avelumab and Durvalumab are monoclonal antibodies against PDL-1 present on cancer cells.
  2. CTLA-4 Inhibitor:
    Normally CD-80 or CD-86 present on antigen presenting cells bind to CD-28 present on T-cells. Cytotoxic T-lymphocyte Antigen-4 (CTLA-4) is a CD-28 homologue expressed on T-cells. Binding of this with CD-80/86 molecules inhibit the T-cells. Ipilimumab acts as CTLA-4 inhibitor resulting in T-cell activation and destruction of cancer cells. It is approved for treatment of malignant melanoma.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman 13th edition page 629

questions.text: Broken vaccine vial will be discarded in:
Wobble hypothesis explains which of the following concepts of the genetic code?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Degeneracy means multiple codes for one amino acid.
  • The degeneracy of the genetic code resides mostly in the last nucleotide of the codon triplet, suggesting that the base pairing between this last nucleotide and the corresponding nucleotide of the anticodon is not strictly by the Watson-Crick rule.
  • This is called wobble; the pairing of the codon and anticodon can "wobble" at this specific nucleotide-to-nucleotide pairing site. For example, the two codons for arginine, AGA and AGG, can bind to the same anticodon having an uracil at its 5' end (UCU). Similarly, three codons for glycine-GGU, GGC, and GGA-can form a base pair from one anticodon, 3' CCI 5' (ie, I, inosine, can base pair with U, C, and A). Inosine is generated by deamination of adenine.
  • Option B: Unambiguous means One code specify one amino acid only, never more than one
  • Option C: Non-punctuated (Comaless) means read continuous.
  • Option D: Universal: same in all species, common evolution, Exception human mitochondrial codons where, UGA - codes for Tryp instead of Stop, AUA - codes for Met instead of Isoleu, CUA - codes for Thr instead of leucine

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, chapter 37, Page 396

questions.solution:
In the given image, there is a circular wound with only tattooing, without any blackening, singeing and burning suggestive of wound caused by rifled firearm intermediate shot.

  1. Contact shot - Here the muzzle end is in contact with body. It may be firm/hard/tight contact or loose contact or angled contact.
  2. Close shot - Here the victim is within the distance travelled by flame.
  3. Near shot - Here the victim is within the range of soot and smoke but outside the range of flame.
  4. Intermediate shot - Here the victim is within the range of powder particles but outside the range of soot and smoke.
  5. Distant shot - Here the victim is beyond the range of all the products of firing except the bullet.

Appearance of wounds in various ranges in rifled firearms:

Firm contact: Wound of entry + Muzzle impression.

Loose contact: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Blackening (corona) + Burning & singeing (Muzzle impression is unlikely)

Angled contact: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Partial muzzle impression + Burning & Singeing + Blackening + Tattooing.

Close shot: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Burning & Singeing + Blackening + Tattooing.

Near shot: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Blackening + Tattooing.

Intermediate shot: Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar + Tattooing.

Distant shot; Wound of entry with grease collar & abrasion collar.

References: Textbook of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, Anil Aggrawal, Page No. 276, 277; The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 164 - 167

questions.text: A patient came with fever, cough and night sweats for more than 15 days. He tested negative for AFB Smear examination but chest x-ray is suggestive of TB. What is the next step of management?
questions.solution:
Cartridge-Based Nucleic Acid Amplification Test (CBNAAT), also known as the Genexpert Ultra Test, is a rapid molecular diagnostic test used to detect Tuberculosis (TB) and drug-resistant strains of TB. Here's how it works:

  1. Purpose: CBNAAT helps detect active TB infections by analyzing the DNA of the TB bacteria in a sputum sample. It's considered a gold standard test for TB diagnosis.
  2. Detection: CBNAAT detects DNA sequences specific for Mycobacterium tuberculosis and also identifies rifampicin resistance using polymerase chain reaction (PCR).

questions.text: Most common opportunistic infection after renal transplant?
questions.solution:
CMV infection after transplant is associated with high morbidity and mortality. Plasma viral load and a rise in IgM is diagnostic. Treatment is Valgancyclovir.

BK polyoma virus infection occurs due to reactivation of dormant virus in the urothelial cells. It leads to graft rejection. Monitoring of viral load is needed. Renal biopsy shows interstitial nephritis, cytopathic changes of virus in tubular epithelial cells and viral antigens in the allograft. Leflunomide, Cidofovir, quinolones are effective against the viral helicase. Reduction in dose of immunosuppression is needed. IvIg has been used with questionable benefit

questions.text: A woman with 32 weeks of gestation presents with complaints of difficulty in breathing and walking. Her fetal movements were normal. On examination, abdomen is tense but not tender, Symphysis-fundal height is 41 cm, fetal parts are not easily felt. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Normal Amniotic Fluid Index: 5 to 24 cm

  • Polyhydramnios is when you have too much amniotic fluid. Amniotic fluid is the fluid that surrounds your baby while they're in your body before birth. It's very important for your baby's development.
  • AFI: >25 cm in polyhydramnios
  • Most common cause of severe/early onset polyhydramnios: GI anomalies like esophageal atresia, duodenal atresia, cleft palate.

Management:

  • Polyhydramnios + breathlessness - therapeutic amniocentesis
  • Polyhydramnios can lead to preterm labour - managed with Corticosteroids and tocolytics
  • No tocolytics after 34 weeks
  • Polyhydramnios + Full term pregnancy in labour - Oxytocin followed by controlled Artificial Rupture of membranes.

Reference: Dutta's textbook of obstetrics 9th edition, chapter 3, page no. 37

pellagra, a systemic disease caused by vitamin B3 (niacin) deficiency. Here are the key points:

questions.text: A 45-year-old male came with acute loss of hair on head & eye brows. The wife had given history of behavioural changes. The doctor examined the nails & made the diagnosis. The condition is
questions.solution:
FEATURES OF THALLIUM POISONING

SYMPTOMS:

A. ACUTE POISONING

  • In mild cases joint pains in legs and feet, loss of appetite, stomatitis and drowsiness occur, which pass off in a few days.
  • In severe cases, there is colic, vomiting, pain in muscles, joints and nerves, lethargy, motor and sensory neuropathies, convulsions, psychosis, optic neuritis, tremors, delirium and coma.
  • Hair loss occurs after one to two weeks. Large tufts tend to come away. Loss of outer third of eyebrows is said to be very significant (Madarosis).
  • Maculo-papular skin eruption having butterfly distribution on face is characteristic.
  • There may be Mees lines on the nails.
  • Death occurs due to respiratory failure due to paralysis of respiratory muscles.
  • After recovery, the patient may suffer from peripheral neuritis resembling Guillain-Barre polyneuritis.

B. CHRONIC POISONING: Thallium triad is characterised by alopecia, skin rashes, painful peripheral neuropathy and mental confusion with lethargy.

ARSENIC POISONING

A. ACUTE POISONING

  1. The Fulminant Type: Massive doses (3 to 5 gm) of arsenic when rapidly absorbed cause death in 1 to 3 hours from shock and peripheral vascular failure. All the capillaries are markedly dilated, especially in the splanchnic area with a marked fall of blood pressure. Arsenic also has a direct action on heart muscle. In this type, gastrointestinal symptoms are absent.
  2. The Gastro enteric Type: This is the common form of acute poisoning and resembles bacterial food poisoning.
    • G.I.T.: Constriction in the throat and difficulty in swallowing; burning and colicky pain in oesophagus, stomach and bowel occur. Intense thirst and severe vomiting which may be projectile are the constant symptoms. Purging (within 1 to 3 hours) is usually accompanied by tenesmus, pain and irritation about the anus. The stools are expelled frequently and involuntarily and are dark-coloured, stinking, and bloody, but later become colourless, odourless and watery resembling rice-water stools of cholera. A garlicky odour of breath and faeces may be noted.
    • Hepatic: Fatty infiltration.
    • Renal: Oliguria, uremia; urine contains albumin, red cells and casts, pain during micturition.
    • C.V.S.: Acute circulatory collapse with vasodilation, increased vascular permeability, ventricular tachycardia, ventricular fibrillation.
    • C.N.S: Headache, vertigo, hyperthermia, tremors, convulsions, coma, general paralysis. A peripheral neuropathy that is more sensory than motor can occur symmetric, distal glove and stocking distribution after one to two weeks of acute or chronic exposures.
    • Skin: Delayed loss of hair, skin eruptions.
  3. Narcotic Form: In this form, the gastrointestinal symptoms are very slight. There is giddiness, formication and tenderness of the muscles, delirium, coma and death.

B. Signs & symptoms of Chronic Arsenic Poisoning:

  • Earliest sign is emaciation.
  • Catarrhal changes - Rhinitis, lacrimation, conjunctivitis, bronchial catarrh
  • Hyperpigmentation of palms and soles is seen. It mimics Addison's disease.
  • Hyperkeratosis of palm and soles.
  • Rashes resembling fading measles
  • Rain drop brown pigmentation
  • Black foot disease is caused. It is a gangrenous change.
  • Aldrich-Mee's lines (leukonychia) are seen (Multiple, transverse parallel white lines in the nails. Takes about 30 days after first exposure. Also seen in thallium poisoning).
  • Cancer (A precancerous lesion called Bowen's disease, Basal cell carcinoma, Small cell carcinoma, Ca lung and Ca bladder)

HYDRARGYRISM/MERCURY POISONING:

Chronic exposure to elemental mercury yields a classic triad of gingivitis and salivation, tremors and neuropsychiatric changes.

  • The symptoms are salivation, inflammation of gums and occasionally a blue line at their junction with teeth, sore mouth, and throat, loosening of teeth, gastrointestinal disturbances, anaemia, anorexia, loss of weight and chronic inflammation of kidneys with progressive uraemia.
  • Tremors (sometimes called Danbury tremors) occur first in the hands, then progress to lips and tongue and finally involve arms and legs. The tremor is moderately coarse and is interspersed by jerky movements.
  • The advanced condition is called hatter's shakes or glass-blower's shakes, because they are common in persons working in glassblowing and hat industries. The patient then becomes unable to dress himself. Write legibly or walk properly. The most severe form is known as concussio mercurialis, in which no activity is possible.
  • Mercurial erythrism is seen in persons working with mercury in minor manufacturing firms. This term is used to refer to the psychological effects of mercury toxicity. These include anxiety, depression, shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, delusions and hallucinations, or suicidal melancholia, or manic depressive psychosis (mad hatter), emotional instability, loss of memory and insomnia.
  • Mercuria lentis is a peculiar eye change due to exposure to the vapour of mercury. It is due to brownish deposit of mercury through the cornea on the anterior lens capsule. Slit-lamp examination demonstrates a malt-brown reflex from the anterior lens capsule. It is bilateral and has no effect on visual acuity.
  • Renal damage results in membranous glomerulonephritis with hyaline casts and fatty casts in the urine. Kidney is the primary target.
  • Acrodynia or pink disease (because it is characterised by a generalised body rash) is thought to be an idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction particularly seen in children. This can be caused by chronic mercury exposure in any form. Hands and feet become puffy, painful, paraesthetic with peeling of skin.

LEAD POISONING:

  • Facial Pallor: The facial pallor particularly about the mouth is one of the earliest and most consistent sign. It seems to be due to vasospasm.
  • Anaemia: There may be polycythaemia with polychromatophilia in early stages, but later there is anaemia which is associated with polychromasia, punctate basophilia, reticulocytosis, poikilocytosis, anisocytosis, nucleated red cells(sideroblasts) and an increase in mononuclear cells, whereas polymorphonuclear cells and platelets are decreased. The anaemia is probably due to decreased survival time of red blood cells and inhibition of haeme synthesis by interference with the incorporation of iron into protoporphyrin. Punctate basophilia or basophilic stippling means the presence of many dark blue-coloured pinhead-sized spots in the cytoplasm of red blood cells, due to toxic action of lead on porphyrin metabolism. Reticulocytes and basophilic stippled cells result from the inhibition of 5 pyrimidine nucleotidase, an impaired ability to rid the cell of RNA degradation products and the aggregation of ribosome. Stippled red cells may also be seen in arsenic and zinc poisoning. Eosinophilia is more common than basophilic stippling.
  • Lead Line: A stippled blue line, called Burtonian line, is seen on the gums in 50 to 70% of cases. It appears due to sub epithelial deposit of granules at the junction with teeth, only near dirty or carious teeth, within a week of exposure, especially on upper jaw. It is due to formation of lead sulphide by the action of hydrogen sulphide formed by decomposed food in the mouth. A similar blue line may be seen in cases of poisoning by mercury, copper, bismuth, iron and silver.
  • Colic and Constipation: It is usually later symptom. Colic of intestines, ureters, uterus and blood vessels occur in 85% of cases. The colic occurs at night and the pain may be very severe. Individual attacks last only a few minutes, but may recur for several days or weeks. Constipation is usual but diarrhoea or vomiting may occur.
  • Lead Palsy: It usually occurs late, and is seen in less than 10% of cases. There may be tremors, numbness, hyperaesthesia, and cramps before the actual muscle weakness. It is commoner in adults than in children, and men are particularly affected. Usually the extensor muscles of the wrist (wrist drop; radial nerve is affected) are affected, but the deltoid, biceps, anterior tibial(foot drop), and rarely muscles of eye or intrinsic muscles of hand or foot are affected. Recovery may be complete but is usually slow.
  • Encephalopathy: Lead encephalopathy, in some form is said to be present in almost every case of plumbism. It is common in children often associated with tetraethyl lead. The symptoms are vomiting, headache, insomnia, visual disturbances, irritability, restlessness, delirium, hallucinations, convulsions, coma and death. Lead encephalopathy is usually irreversible and about 85% have permanent brain damage.
  • Cardiovascular System and Kidneys: Lead causes vascular constriction, leading to hypertension and permanent arteriolar degeneration. Chronic arteriosclerotic nephritis and interstitial nephritis occur.
  • Reproductive System: Menstrual derangements, such as amenorrhoea, dysmenorrhoea, menorrhagia, sterility of both sexes and abortion are frequent. Abortion occurs in pregnant women between 3 to 6 months.
  • Other Systems: They are dyspepsia, anorexia, emaciation, general weakness, exhaustion, irritability, foul breath, headache, vertigo, loss of hair and drowsiness. Retinal stippling is noticed by ophthalmoscopic examination showing presence of greyish glistening lead particles in the early phase of poisoning.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, K S Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 415

questions.text: A 25-year-old female who was sexually active with multiple sexual partners presents with swelling in the wall of labia majora. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Bartholin abscess Causes. A Bartholin abscess forms when a small opening(duct) from the gland gets blocked. Fluid in the gland builds up and may become infected. Fluid may build up over many years before an abscess occurs.

Soaking in a tub filled with a few inches of warm water(sitz bath) several times a day for three or four days may help a small, infected cyst to rupture and drain on its own. Surgical drainage. You may need surgery to drain a cyst that's infected or very large.

Topical treatments

  • Tea tree oil: Applying a mixture of tea tree oil and castor oil to the abscess may encourage drainage. Tea tree oil has natural antibacterial properties....
  • Apple cider vinegar (ACV): Typically, people who use ACV to treat a Bartholin's abscess dilute it and apply it to the cyst with a cotton ball.

questions.text: A 35 year old obese female with excessive facial hair presents with lesions as shown. She is not responding to isotretinoin and antibiotics. What is the next step?
questions.solution:
The acne is not responding to routine treatments which would otherwise work

Additionally, the patient is middle aged, obsess, high BMI and suffers from hirsutism and acne in lower face – indicators of hormonal acne.

Thus she requires evaluation for hyperandrogenism

Hormonal acne lesions located mainly on the lower part of the face, including the mandibular region, the perioral region and the chin, conferring a U-shape.

Testosterone, Dehydroepiandrosterone Sulfate (SDHEA) and Dihydrotestosterone (DHT) stimulate sebaceous gland growth and sebum production.

The association of acne with an endocrinopathy characterized by hyper-androgenism usually presents other clinical signs such as: hirsutism, seborrhoea, alopecia, menstrual disorders, ovulatory dysfunction, infertility, early puberty, metabolic syndrome and virilization.

The main endocrinopathies that occur with hyper-androgenism are: Polycystic ovary syndrome POS, late congenital adrenal hyperplasia or disfunction and, more rarely, ovarian, adrenal, pituitary and hypothalamic tumors.

Reference: Rooks textbook of Dermatology, 9th edition, chapter 90, page 90.15

questions.text: Which of the following is not a perineal approach for rectal prolapse?
questions.solution:
The common disease in multiparous females and psychiatric males is rectal prolapse. It can be approached by two methods: 1- Via abdominal approach 2- Via perineal approach

In abdominal approach, the rectum is pulled inside and fixed to the sacrum with a mesh.:

  • In Ripstein, the mesh is placed anteriorly i.e; anterior rectopexy.
  • In modified Ripstein (Well’s), the mesh is placed posteriorly.
  • Frykman Golberg resection rectopexy- The extra colon is resected and anastomosed. i.e; resection type rectopexy.
  • In posterior dissection, the injury of nerves posterior to rectum may occur and patients may develop many sexual problems. Therefore, in young male patients, dissection is done anteriorly and fixing the hockey stick shaped biological mesh from anterior rectum to sacrum. This is ventral rectopexy. Biological mesh is used to avoid adhesions.

Perineal approach can be done under spinal anaesthesia. This approach has high recurrence rate. Usually done for very old patients.:

  • Thiersch wiring procedure, Altemeier’s resection type procedure, Delorme mucosal plication operation.

questions.text: A patient with bronchial asthma is found to be havig raised intra-ocular pressure. Treatment of open angle glaucoma in this patient is
questions.solution:
Latanoprost Instilled in the eye, this PAGEF2α derivative has shown efficacy similar to timolol (i.o.t. reduction by 25–35%) and the effect is well sustained over the long-term. It reduces i.o.t. in normal pressure glaucoma also.

Though ocular irritation and pain are relatively frequent, no systemic side effects are reported. Blurring of vision, increased iris pigmentation, thickening and darkening of eyelashes have occurred in some cases. Macular edema can develop during treatment with any PAGEF2α analogue, especially in aphakic patients; a watch should be kept to detect it early.

Because of good efficacy, once daily application and absence of systemic complications, PAGE analogues have become the first choice drugs for open angle glaucoma. High cost is a disadvantage.

Reference: K D Tripathi 8th edition page 169

questions.text: A patient diagnosed with deep vein thrombosis was kept under anticoagulant therapy. Next day she presented with this condition depicted in the picture below. Which of the following drugs would have caused this?
questions.solution:
The figure shows the dermal vascular necrosis which is an early adverse effect of warfarin. It is mainly seen in patients with genetic protein C deficiency.

This is also dermal vascular necrosis also known as 'purple toe syndrome'

Skin Necrosis. Warfarin-induced skin necrosis is a rare complication characterized by the appearance of skin lesions 3–10 days after treatment is initiated. The lesions typically are on the extremities, but adipose tissue, the penis, and the female breast also may be involved. Skin necrosis occurs in patients with protein C or S deficiency or in those with heparin-induced thrombocytopenia.

Other Toxicities. A reversible, sometimes painful, blue-tinged discoloration of the plantar surfaces and sides of the toes that blanches with pressure and fades with elevation of the legs (purple toe syndrome) may develop 3-8 weeks after initiation of therapy with warfarin; cholesterol emboli released from atheromatous plaques have been implicated as the cause. Other infrequent reactions include alopecia, urticaria, dermatitis, fever, nausea, diarrhoea, abdominal cramps, and anorexia.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman 13th edition p594

questions.text: A labourer working in hot summer day became unconscious. On examination skin was red, hot and dry. What is unlikely to be found in patient?
questions.solution:
• HEAT CRAMPS (miner’s cramps, stoker’s cramps, or fireman’s cramps): They are caused by a rapid dehydration of body through the loss of water and salt in the sweat. It is seen in workers in high temperature when sweating has been profuse. The onset is usually sudden. Severe and painful paroxysmal cramps affecting the muscles of the arms, legs and abdomen occur. The face is flushed, the pupils dilated, and the patient complains of dizziness, tinnitus, headache, and vomiting. Intravenous injection of saline gives rapid relief.
  • HEAT PROSTRATION (heat exhaustion, heat syncope, or heat collapse): Heat prostration is a condition of collapse without increase in body temperature, which follows exposure to excessive heat. It is precipitated by muscular work and unsuitable clothing. There is extreme exhaustion and peripheral vascular collapse. The patient feels suddenly weak, giddy and sick. The face is pale, the skin cold, the temperature subnormal. The pupils are dilated, the pulse small and thready and the respiration sighing. The patient usually recovers if placed at rest, but death may take place from heart failure.

HEAT HYPERPYREXIA/HEAT STROKE

  • Occurs when the body is exposed to high temperature with high humidity
  • The term ‘Thermic fever’ or ‘Sun stroke’ is used when there has been direct exposure to the sun
  • There is impaired function of heat regulating system of the body
  • There is failure of cutaneous blood circulation
  • High temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, muscular activity and lack of acclimatization are the principal factors in initiation
  • In case of 100% humidity, environmental temperature of 320C may lead to heat stroke

Clinical features

  • Core body (Rectal) temperature increases above the level of 40.5°C.
  • Skin → Hot & dry, there is absence of sweating
  • Breathing → Rapid, deep and Kussmaul type
  • B.P. → Initial hypertension followed by hypotension
  • HR → Tachycardia
  • Pupils → Constricted
  • Headache, dizziness, nausea, vomiting
  • Restlessness, confusion, disorientation, drowsiness, delirium
  • Collapse and unconsciousness

Treatment

  • Remove the patient to a cooler environment
  • Remove the clothes
  • Reduce the body temperature by ice water sponging
  • Monitor heart rate and respiratory rate
  • I.V. diazepam in case of convulsion
  • I.V. fluids and electrolytes

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 244

questions.text: Green colour in triage signifies:
questions.solution:
Five categories or levels of triage:

  • Red: The individual needs immediate attention for a critical life-threatening injury or illness and may be transported first for medical help.
  • Yellow: The individual has serious injuries that need immediate attention. In some systems, yellow tags are transported first because they have a better chance of recovery than red-tagged patients.
  • Green: This could indicate less serious or minor injuries that are non-life-threatening. Transport may be delayed.
  • Black: This could indicate an individual is deceased or mortally wounded. It may mean that they are beyond help and, therefore, are a lower priority than those who can be helped.
  • White: The individual doesn't have an injury or illness.

questions.text: A patient with squamous cell carcinoma of the lung has undergone pneumonectomy. During the procedure blackish hilar lymph nodes of 1 cm are seen. Identify the cause of pigmentation.
questions.solution:
• This can be the case of coal worker's pneumoconiosis, which later turned into carcinoma.
  • This is the commonest form of pneumoconiosis and is defined as the lung disease resulting from inhalation of coal dust particles, especially in coal-miners engaged in handling soft bituminous coal for a number of years, often 20 to 30 years.
  • It exists in 2 forms-a milder form of the disease called simple coal workers- pneumoconiosis and an advanced form termed progressive massive fibrosis (complicated coal-miners- pneumoconiosis).
  • Anthracosis, on the other hand, is not a lung disease in true sense but is the common, benign and asymptomatic accumulation of carbon dust in the lungs of most urban dwellers due to atmospheric pollution and cigarette smoke (anthracite refers to coal).
  • Anthracotic pigment is deposited in the macrophages in the alveoli and around the respiratory bronchi o les and into the draining lymph nodes but does not produce any respiratory difficulty or radiologic changes.

Reference: Harshmohan textbook of pathology, 7th edition, Page- 468

questions.text: A patient on risperidone comes to the emergency room with an upward fixed gaze. How do you manage?
questions.solution:
Acute muscular dystonias

Bizarre muscle spasms, mostly involving linguo-facial muscles-grimacing, tongue thrusting, torticollis, locked jaw; occurs within a few hours of a single dose or at the most in the first week of therapy. It is more common in children below 10 years and in girls, particularly after parenteral administration; overall incidence is 2%. It lasts for one to few hours and then resolves spontaneously. One of the central anticholinergics, Promethazine or hydroxyzine injected i.m. clears the reaction within 10-15 min.

Reference:K D Triathi 8th edition page 471

Nuclear features- Orphan Annie’s eyed nucleus in which the nucleus has no nucleoli

questions.text: A patient was suspected of having brucellosis. A serum sample was sent for a standard agglutination test. It came negative initially but after dilution of the serum sample the test was positive. What could be the reason for the initial negative test?
questions.solution:
There are two phenomena for antigen antibody reactions. Prozone phenomenon and post zone phenomenon.

In the prozone phenomenon there is an excess of antibodies and in the post zone phenomenon there is antigen excess.

Antigen antibody reaction occurs when an equal number of antigen binds with an equal number of antibodies.

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker Textbook of Microbiology 10th Edition. Page no-107

questions.text: Section 314 of IPC deals with
questions.solution:
LEGAL ASPECTS OF CRIMINAL ABORTION:

  • Under Sec. 312, I.P.C. whoever voluntarily causes criminal abortion is liable for imprisonment up to three years, and/or fine; and if the woman is quick with child the imprisonment may extend up to seven years. It is necessary that the woman should be pregnant, and that abortion should be carried with her consent. Both the person causing the abortion and the woman are liable for punishment.
  • Under Sec. 313, if the miscarriage is caused without the consent of the woman, the imprisonment may be up to ten years.
  • Under Sec. 314, if a pregnant woman dies from an act intended to cause miscarriage, the offender is liable to be punished with rigorous imprisonment which shall not be less than ten years and also fine up to two lakh rupees.
  • Under Sec. 315, a person doing an act intended to prevent the child from being born alive or to cause to die after its birth, is liable to be punished with imprisonment up to ten years.
  • Under Sec. 316, causing death of quick unborn child by any act amounts to culpable homicide, and the punishment may extend up to ten years imprisonment.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 312

questions.text: A 42 year old chronic alcoholic came to ED with altered sensorium, confusion and agitation. His laboratory results show ALT 150 U/L & AST 180 U/L. Which of the following drugs would have been used to stabilize the patient?
questions.solution:
Has slow oral absorption. Being less lipid-soluble than diazepam, its rate of entry in the brain is slower. The plasma t½ is shorter (10-20 hours); no active metabolite is produced, since it is directly conjugated with glucuronic acid, and is suitable for older patients.

However, it is quite sedative and capable of producing marked amnesia when injected i.v. Injection site complications are minor. Therefore, it is the only BZD recommended for i.m. use.

Lorazepam has been preferred for short lasting anxiety states, panic, OCD and tension syndromes, as well as for psychosomatic diseases and for i.v. use in status epilepticus.

Reference: K D Tripathi 8th edition page 494

questions.text: What is the differentiating feature between IBS and organic GI disease?
questions.solution:
Irritable bowel syndrome is a functional bowel disorder which is non inflammatory. The unifying feature of inflammatory diarrhoea due to any cause is the presence of leukocytes or leukocyte derived protein Calprotectin in stools.

Abdominal pain, diarrhoea and presence of mucous in stools can be seen in IBS as well as inflammatory diarrhoea. Blood in stools , nocturnal symptoms and weight loss is uncommon in IBS.

Another inflammatory marker in stool is Fecal Lactoferrin, which is also present in activated neutrophils. Both of them can be used in diagnosis of relapses of inflammatory bowel disease from IBS or bacterial overgrowth. Fecal calprotectin is also having the advantage of being a sensitive marker of Colonic or ileocolonic inflammation rather than isolated ilial inflammation.

questions.text: A patient was admitted for surgery and halothane is being planned to be used as an anaesthetic agent. The patient was explained about the adverse effect of malignant hyperthermia with this drug. Which of the following drugs may also result in malignant hyperthermia?
questions.solution:
Malignant hyperthermia produced by halothane and isoflurane in rare (genetically predisposed) individuals is more common in patients receiving SCh as well.

Reference: K D Tripathi 8th edition page 380

questions.text: A patient with history of travel to Africa developed jaundice with Hemorrhagic fever and yellow conjunctiva. He was given treatment but died. Which of the following vaccines could have prevented his death?
questions.solution: Yellow fever is a lethal viral hemorrhagic fever occurring in Africa and South America. A highly effective live vaccine (17D) is widely used for travelers to and residents of areas in which yellow fever is endemic

questions.text: Spot the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Diagnosis is made using slit lamp biomicroscopy and intraocular pressure measurement. Deposition of white fluffy material on the anterior lens capsule and pupillary margin and iris transillumination defects can be visualized in many cases. Gonioscopy may show increased pigment deposit on the trabecular meshwork.

Physical examination

Signs:

  • Increased intraocular pressure
  • Possible glaucomatous damage to optic nerve
  • Poor dilation with peripupillary transillumination defect
  • Fibrillar white flaky deposits on the anterior lens capsule(Hoarfrost Ring)
  • Fibrillar white flaky deposits on at pupillary border
  • Hyperpigmentation of the trabecular meshwork(TM) with an open angle on gonioscopy
  • Sampaolesi line, abundance of linear pigment anterior to the TM at or anterior to Schwalbe's line(not pathognomonic; also seen in pigment dispersion syndrome)

Symptoms:

  • No associated symptoms aside from possibly with significantly increased intraocular pressure

Reference: Parson, Section IV, Page no. 147-150.

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with defects in formation of collagen?
questions.solution:
• Option A: In the vitamin D deficiency disease rickets, the bones of children are under mineralized as a result of poor absorption of calcium. Similar problems occur as a result of deficiency during the adolescent growth spurt. Osteomalacia in adults results from the demineralization of bone, especially in women who have little exposure to sunlight, especially after several pregnancies.
  • Option B: Thiamin deficiency can result in three distinct syndromes: a chronic peripheral neuritis, beriberi, which may or may not be associated with heart failure and edema; acute pernicious (fulminating) beriberi (Shoshin beriberi), in which heart failure and metabolic abnormalities predominate, without peripheral neuritis; and Wernicke encephalopathy with Korsakoff psychosis, which is associated especially with alcohol and narcotic abuse.
  • Option C: Vitamin C deficiency causes scurvy. Signs of vitamin C deficiency include skin changes, fragility of blood capillaries, gum decay, tooth loss, and bone fracture, which can be attributed to impaired collagen synthesis. Proline and lysine hydroxylases are required for the postsynthetic modification of procollagen to collagen, both these enzymes require vitamin C.
  • Option D: Pellagra is caused by deficiency of tryptophan & niacin. Pellagra is characterized by photosensitive dermatitis. As the condition progresses, there is depressive psychosis and possibly diarrhoea. Untreated pellagra is fatal.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, Chapter 44, Page 540

questions.text: Which of the following is not useful in the management of Sickle cell anemia?
questions.solution:
• Hydroxyurea is the standard treatment in all cases of sickle cell anemia. It works by increasing the levels of HbF. It should be started in the first year of life.
  • Voxelotor increases oxygen affinity of hemoglobin and thereby reduces the rbc polymerization.
  • L glutamine acts by reducing the oxidative stress
  • Crizanlizumab is the monoclonal antibody approved for the treatment of sickle cell anemia. It inhibits the p selectin and there by prevents endothelial adhesions
  • Babtelovimab is the monoclonal antibody against the spike protein of SARS CoV, used in the treatment of covid 19.

questions.text: Post-dural puncture headache is a common complication following neuraxial blockade. The definitive management involves:
questions.solution:
Post-dural puncture headache, a prevalent complication after neuraxial blockade, finds effective resolution through an epidural blood patch. This intervention entails injecting autologous blood (usually 15 to 20 mL) into the epidural space, either at the level of or one interspace below the dural puncture site. The mechanism involves mitigating further cerebrospinal fluid leakage, promoting prompt relief from the associated headache.

Reference: Morgan anaesthesia, edition 6, page no 92

questions.text: A male presented with urethral discharge as shown in the picture. What can be the cause?

This case looks like gonococcal infection. Gonococci in gram negative diplococci.

It is a sexually transmitted infection.

Patient complains of discharge from penis, pain in micturition.

In females, there is a discharged from the cervix.

The sample when stained by gram stain shows gram negative diplococci.

Both the male and female requires treatment even when one of them is asymptomatic.

questions.text: A 60-year-old patient presented with acute onset chest pain radiating to the neck and interscapular region. His blood pressure in right arm is 100/60 and in left arm is 170/90. Chest Xray shows mediastinal widening. What is the diagnosis?

On the basis of the difference of blood pressure on both arms it shows that there is evidence of reduced blood in both extremities. Along with mediastinal widening, it is suggestive of acute aortic dissection.

questions.text: Route of metastasis of prostate cancer to lumbar vertebrae

Prostatic venous plexus, also known as Santorini Venous Plexus carries the prostatic cancer to the lumbar vertebrae.

questions.text: Water hammer pulse seen in which of the following?
questions.solution:
Water hammer pulse is seen in AR.

Corrigan pulse describes the excessive visible pulsations of arteries in patients with aortic valve insufficiency, most obvious in the head and superior extremity arteries when the patient is upright; in particular, the subclavian, carotid, temporal, brachial, and palmar arteries.

In MS the pulse will be low volume. In AS the pulse will be slow rising low volume pulse(Parvus et tardus)

questions.text: Cytochrome C oxidase is inhibited by all except?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Methane will not inhibit cytochrome c oxidase.
  • Option B, Option C & Option D: H2S, carbon monoxide (CO) and cyanide inhibit Complex IV and can therefore totally arrest respiration.
  • Cytochrome c oxidase is complex IV of electron transport chain.

Inhibitors of the respiratory chain provided knowledge about the mechanism of action of several poisons & drugs which are fatal at high dose.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, Chapter 13, Page 123

questions.text: A 5-year-old child with features of acute tonsillitis, is complaining of ear pain. The nerve responsible for the ear pain is

questions.text: A 50-year-old patient with a history of trauma one week back presents with confusion and ataxia. He is on treatment for alcohol dependence and his last intake was 2 weeks back. CT scan reveals the following finding. Diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• An SDH is a collection of acute blood products that lies in or between the inner border cell layer of the dura and the arachnoid.
  • Trauma is the most common cause of aSDH. Tearing of bridging cortical veins as they cross the subdural space to enter a dural venous sinus (usually the superior sagittal sinus) is the most common etiology.
  • Cortical vein lacerations can occur with either a skull fracture or the sudden changes in velocity and brain rotation that occur during nonimpact closed head injury.
  • Most aSDHs spread diffusely over the affected hemisphere and are therefore typically crescent-shaped.

Reference: Osborn Brain edition 2nd edition, Page 26

questions.text: A 25-year-old female with history of 2 weeks amenorrhea came in emergency department with c/o scanty vaginal bleeding. on examination no adnexal mass noted. In lab investigation HCG was 1400mlU/ml, on USG, uterus was bulky, trilaminar endometrium was seen. Patient vitals are stable, What is the next step to do?
questions.solution:
Pregnancy of unknown origin

questions.text: Identify the cell
questions.solution:
• Blood smear in chronic renal failure showing numerous burr cells (echinocytes)
  • Usually signs and symptoms of chronic renal failure predominate and anaemia is discovered incidentally. Rarely, manifestations of renal failure are minimal and patient presents with anaemia.
  • Degree of anaemia roughly corresponds with the level of blood urea nitrogen (BUN); the greater concentration of blood urea nitrogen is associated with more severe anaemia.
  • The anaemia is typically normocytic and normochromic with normal reticulocyte count. Burr cells (red cells with many tiny regularly placed projections on surface) are frequent.

Reference: Essentials of hematology, 2nd edition, Page- 115

questions.text: Which among the following is the most sensitive investigation for generalized myasthenia gravis ?
questions.solution: Single-fiber electromyography (SFEMG) is a selective EMG recording technique that allows identification of action potentials from individual muscle fibers. When a motor axon is depolarized the action potentials travel distally and excite the muscle fiber more or less at the same time. The variation in the time interval between the two action potentials of the same motor unit (as occurs in neuromuscular junction disorders is called as "jitter")

questions.text: What is the name of the incision shown below?
questions.solution:
It is a modified Gibson incision.

Kocher's incision- rights sub coastal incision- cholecystectomy/ gall bladder surgeries

Rooftop/ bucket handle/ Chevron incision- V shaped subcostal incision- For pancreatic surgeries

Mercedes Benz Incision- Inverted Y shaped- liver surgeries

Gibson incision- made parallel to inguinal ligament- to approach ureter

Modified Gibson incision- a slightly curved Gibson Incision- to approach ureter

Maylard incision- a transverse incision at the lower abdominal wall

Marwedel incision- T shaped for spleen and pancreas surgeries. This area is weak. So a modified incision called Bevan incision is used.

Kehr's incision

Robson incision- Reverse Kehr's incision

Mason incision

These incisions are more suitable than Kocher's incision when biliary trapped anastomosis is desired. It is therefore ideal for choledocho- duodenostomy, choledocho-jejunostomy and cholecysto-jejunostomy

Incisions used for appendix:

  • Grid iron (Macarthur/ McBurney) incision- Most commonly used
  • Horizontal Lanz incision/ Davis- Rockey incision
  • Battle's incision- perpendicular incision used in difficult appendix operations. It paramedian and is towards McBurney's point. No more done

questions.text: High anion gap acidosis is seen in all except:
questions.solution:
• Anion Gap is difference between measured cation & anions

AG = (Na+ + K+) - (Cl- + HCO3-)

  • Normal value: 12 + 2 mmol/l (10 - 14)
  • Indicate unmeasured anions like protein, phosphate, sulphates, organic acids etc
  • High anion gap most commonly associated with metabolic acidosis.
  • When only loss of HCO3- AG ↑ & When loss of HCO3- associated with ↑ reabsorption of Cl- (Hyperchloremia) or loss of Na+ & K+ also AG is normal
  • Clinically metabolic acidosis divided into High anion gap metabolic acidosis (HAGMA) or normal anion gap metabolic acidosis (NAGMA)
  • Option A: Renal failure leads to HAGMA, whereas Renal tubular acidosis leads to NAGMA.
  • Option B: DKA usually occurs in insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus in association with cessation of insulin or an intercurrent illness such as an infection, gastroenteritis, pancreatitis, or myocardial infarction, which increases insulin requirements temporarily and acutely, and is characterized by hyperglycemia, ketonemia, and a high-AG acidosis.
  • Option C:
  • An increase in plasma l-lactate may be secondary to poor tissue perfusion (type A)-circulatory insufficiency (shock, cardiac failure), severe anemia, mitochondrial enzyme defects, and inhibitors (carbon monoxide, cyanide)-or to aerobic disorders (type B)-malignancies, nucleoside analogue reverse transcriptase inhibitors in HIV, diabetes mellitus, renal or hepatic failure, thiamine deficiency, severe infections (cholera, malaria), seizures, or drugs/toxins (biguanides, ethanol, and the toxic alcohols: ethylene glycol, methanol, or propylene glycol).
  • Unrecognized bowel ischemia or infarction in a patient with severe atherosclerosis or cardiac decompensation receiving vasopressors is a common cause of lactic acidosis in elderly patients. Pyroglutamic acidemia may occur in critically ill patients
  • Option D: Salicylate intoxication in adults usually causes respiratory alkalosis or a mixture of high-AG metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. Only a portion of the AG is due to salicylates. Lactic acid production is also often increased.

Reference: Harrison's principle of internal medicine 21st edition, Chapter 55, Page 361

questions.text: Post lap hernia patient complaints of pain. Which of the following nerve is injured?

questions.text: A 70 year old patient has diabetes mellitus and hypertension. He presents with a late stage chronic kidney. Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs require least dose modification in renal disease?
questions.solution:
DPP-4 Inhibitors:

Sitagliptin, vildagliptin, saxagliptin, alogliptin and linagliptin prolong the action of endogenous GLP-1 by inhibiting its metabolism through DPP-4:

  • Unlike incretin-mimetic drugs, these do not cause nausea or weight loss.
  • Most common adverse effect of DPP-4 inhibitors is nasopharyngitis and upper respiratory tract infections. These drugs are also associated with acute pancreatitis.
  • DPP-4 inhibitors are effective orally.
  • These drugs require dose adjustment in renal failure except linagliptin.
  • Vildagliptin can cause hepatitis and requires dose adjustment in both renal as well as hepatic disease.
  • Linagliptin and saxagliptin increase the risk of heart failure.

Reference: Goodman & Gilman 13th editon page 879

questions.text: A patient presented with a headache for 6 months. She took analgesics regularly. The headache has been increasing and became severe for the past 3 days. She decided to stop medications, but the pain persists. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
If a person uses analgesics for a prolonged period of time, the headache becomes increasing in frequency and is resistant to preventive medications. After stopping the analgesic, they feel improved, especially if they have been using opioids or barbiturates. The residual headache that they experience after stopping the drug is probably the primary headache that is the underlying problem for the medication use.

The treatment of medication overuse of headache is to reduce the dose of the analgesic by !0% every 1-2 weeks. Small dose NSAID can be given for residual headache and the preventive medication can be started.

questions.text: A family consuming predominantly polished rice would present with which of the following deficiencies? Match the vitamin deficiency with the investigation used to detect the deficiency:
questions.solution:
• A family consuming predominantly polished rice likely to have thiamine(vitamin B1) deficiency.
  • Option A: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro. But here likely vitamin deficiency is thiamine.
  • Option B: Xanthurenic acid is excreted in vitamin B6 deficiency.
  • The most widely used method of assessing vitamin B6 status is by the activation of erythrocyte transaminases by pyridoxal phosphate added in vitro.
  • Option C: Riboflavin nutritional status is assessed by measurement of the activation of erythrocyte glutathione reductase by FAD added in vitro. Not transketolase(used in thiamine deficiency).
  • Option D: Thiamin nutritional status can be assessed by erythrocyte transketolase activation.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 31st edition, Chapter 44, Page 534

questions.text: The technique of autopsy that employs the en bloc method of removing thoracic, cervical and abdominal organs together is known as?
questions.solution:
Evisceration Methods (Techniques of autopsy) :

i. Letulle's techniquw:

  • Described by Letulle.
  • Also known as, 'En masse' or 'En bloc' dissection
  • En masse = In a group; all together
  • En bloc = All together or all at the same time
  • In this technique, oral, cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed as one large organ block.
  • Leaves all attachments intact.
  • Commonly done in medical colleges to teach students

ii. Virchow's Method:

  • Organ by organ removal
  • Individual organ removal one by one.
  • Subsequent dissection of isolated organs.
  • Useful for assessing individual organ pathology.
  • Quick and effective for single organ focus.
  • Most common method in India

iii. Gohn's technique:

  • Developed by Ghon.
  • Also known as, 'Block by block' dissection
  • Cervical & thoracic organs, abdominal organs and the urogenital system are removed as separate organ blocks.

iv. In Situ Dissection:

  • Developed by Rokitansky.
  • Also known as In-situ dissection
  • Organs dissected in situ with minimal evisceration.
  • Rarely performed.
  • Done in infected & suspected infection cases.

Reference: Knight's Forensic Pathology, 4th Edition, Page N0. 22; The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 80

questions.text: A patient presents with nail lesions. What is the probable diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Image - coarse irregular pitting, salmon patch, onycholysis - point to diagnosis of nail psoriasis.
  • Onychomycosis:The changes of onychomycosis resemble nail psoriasis, and sometimes it is difficult to distinguish between the two. Nail pitting and oil drop sign are the main features of nail psoriasis. Onychomycosis can be diagnosed by absence of pitting, brown-black nail discoloration, fungal culture, nail clipping with periodic acid Schiff( PAS)and potassium hydroxide (KOH) preparations.
  • Alopecia areata:It usually appears as linear ridging, nail pitting, along with non-scarring patchy alopecia of the scalp or other body areas . Pitting in AA is superficial fine and regular.
  • Lichen planus : Nail involvement presents as thinning of nails with ridges and pterygium formation. Lichen planus also involves the mucosa or skin. The skin manifestations of lichen planus are itchy, purple, polygonal papules or plaques

Reference: Rooks textbook of dermatology, chapter 35, page 35.13

questions.text: Correctly matched statement regarding the splint shown in image
questions.solution:
Turn buckle splint: A dynamic splint producing gradua stretching over contracted joints by its turnbuckle mechanism.

Indications:

  1. Stiff elbow
  2. VIC

Knuckle bender splint: based on the principle of 3 point fixation. When all fingers are loaded with flexion, the extended MCP joint tends to achieve a position of flexion.

Static cock up splint: Maintain wrist in extension with the help of volar support.

Indications: Sprain, Arthritis, Tendinitis of wrist.

Dynamic cock up splint: Maintains wrist in 45 degrees of extension.

Indications: Radial nerve palsy

questions.text: A group of people had pastries late at night followed by bouts of vomiting early in the morning. What could be the cause?

The Cause is food poisoning. Typically occurred after eating pastries.

Patient can also have nausea, vomiting, headache, abdominal pain.

Verotoxin does not cause food poisoning.

questions.text: The following is a good prognostic factor in BIRADS 5 lesion

questions.text: A 50 year old known HIV patient presents with painful lesions on palate as shown below. What is the diagnosis?

questions.text: 18 years old girl with transverse vaginal septum presents to hospital with dysmenorrhea and chronic pelvic pain. Which of the following is the most common complication?
questions.solution:
• Transverse vaginal septum is a rare Mullerian anomaly which is related to vertical fusion disorder. It is an uncommon anomaly that is not associated with a well-defined inheritance pattern.
  • The vase majority of these obstructed mullerian duct abnormalities are first seen at puberty.
  • Hematocolpos, hematometra and hematometrocolpos are some of its most common presentations.
  • Some authors have suggested that retrograde flow through the uterus and falopian tubes could have occured earlier. It may even present before puberty.
  • Transverse vaginal septum is infrequently associated with genitourinary tract, gastrointestinal tract, musculoskeletal, and cardiac malformations. However, it is still prudent to work up patients of the possibility of having any concomitant anomaly.
  • The differential diagnosis of transverse vaginal septum includes imperforate hymen, Mayer-Rokitansky Kuster-Hauser syndrome and vaginal agenesis.

Reference: Berek & Novak’s Gynecology, 16th Edition, Chapter 12, Page no. 604

questions.text: A patient presented with extension of metacarpophalangeal joint and flexion of interphalangeal joint. Which muscle is involved?

• Action of lumbricals:
  • Flex metacarpophalangeal joints
  • Extend interphalangeal joints of 2nd–5th digits
  • The lumbricals and interossei are tested by asking the subject to flex the fingers at the metacarpophalangeal joints against resistance.
  • If lumbricals involve extension of metacarpophalangeal joint and flexion of interphalangealjoint occurs.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-4, 8th Edition, Page No – 68

questions.text: A 47 year old male with HIV presents with refractory diarrhea that has been persistent for the past 3 weeks. What is the most likely organism responsible for this patients condition?
questions.solution:
Cryptosporidium, Isospora belli and microsporidia are the common organisms causing diarrhoea in HIV.

Cryptosporidium: CD4 counts <100. May range from self limiting infection to chronic diarrhoea. Cause infection of biliary tree causing cholecystitis and pancreatitis secondary to papillary stenosis. Diagnosis is by demonstration of oocysts in the stools that are acid fast. Treatment is initiation of ART. Nitazoxonide may benefit.

Microsporidia: the commonest organism is Enterocytozoon bineuesi. They are obligate intra cellular parasites of the enteric cells. They are also found in cells outside the GIT like eye, brain, muscle liver etc. They have been associated with conjunctivitis and hepatitis. They need chromotrope based stains for demonstration of the organism in the stools , because of their small size. Electron microscopy of the stool or intestinal aspirate is needed for definitive diagnosis. Treatment is reconstitution of immune system with ART. Albendazole may be effective.

Isospora belli: clinical features are similar to cryptosporidium. More common in tropics and sub tropics. Oocysts are acid fast and are larger in size. Treatment is very easy and effective with TMP-SMX

questions.text: A patient with cirrhosis undergoes a Liver Biopsy, which Shows eosinophilic material that is cytokeratin positive. what is this material most likely composed of?
questions.solution:
• Mallory bodies or alcoholic hyaline: These are eosinophilic, intracytoplasmic inclusions seen in perinuclear location within swollen and ballooned hepatocytes.
  • They represent aggregates of cytoskeletal intermediate filaments (prekeratin).
  • They can be best visualised with connective tissue stains like Masson's trichrome and chromophobe aniline blue, or by the use of immunoperoxidase methods.
  • Mallory bodies are highly suggestive of, but not specific for, alcoholic hepatitis since Mallory bodies are also found in certain other conditions such as: primary biliary cirrhosis, Indian childhood cirrhosis, cholestatic syndromes, Wilson's disease, intestinal bypass surgery, focal nodular hyperplasia and hepato cellular carcinoma.

Alcoholic hepatitis. Liver cells show ballooning degeneration and necrosis with some containing Mallory's hyaline (Inbox). Fatty change and clusters of neutrophils are also present.

Reference: Harshmohan textbook of pathology, 7th edition, Page- 607

questions.text: A patient presented with seizures, muscle tremors, backward arching of the spine after consuming some herbal medicine. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
Signs and symptoms resemble poisoning due to nux vomica seeds.

Signs and symptoms are seen within 15-30 minutes of ingestion. A 'conscious' seizure is the characteristic presentation of strychnine poisoning.

Findings associated with poisoning are

  1. Bitter taste.
  2. Choking sensation in throat, and stiffness of the neck and face.
  3. Prodromal symptoms: Restlessness, increased acuity of perception, increased rigidity of muscles and muscular twitchings.
  4. Face:Cyanosed, look is anxious, eyes are staring, eyeballs are prominent, and the pupils are dilated. Mouth is filled with bloodstained froth.
  5. Convulsions:The threshold for CNS stimulation is lowered with the result that any sensory stimulus (light, pain, touch, or noise) may produce violent muscular spasm. Initially, clonic but eventually become tonic, and affect all the muscles at the same time.
  • Risus sardonicusresults from raising of patient's eyebrows, bulging of eyes and contraction of the jaw and facial muscles in which the corners of the mouth are drawn back leading to an evil looking grin. This expression can be seen in tetanus too.
  • Convulsions are more marked in anti-gravity muscles resulting in hyperextension (opisthotonos)
  • Sometimes, the spasm of the abdominal muscles may bend the body forward (emprosthotonus)or sideways (pleurosthotonus).
  • Duration of convulsions is about half to 2 min and may recur for 12-24 hours (h). During convulsionsthe patient remains awake and aware of everything around him since strychnine does not cross the blood-brain barrier.
  • In between convulsions, muscles are completely relaxed and breathing is resumed. Patient is usually in pain, exhausted, anxious and anticipating the next series of convulsions.
  • After 5-15 min, on the slightest impulse, such as sudden noise, current of air or on gently touching the patient, another convulsion occurs with increased intensity.
  • Increased muscle tone, hyperreflexia, agitation, restlessness and convulsions lead to profound lactic acidosis, rhabomyolysis and hyperthermia.
  • Death occurs within 4-5 convulsions as the patient cannot breathe. Consciousness is not lost and the mind remains clear till death.At the time of death, the body 'freezes' even in the middle of convulsions resulting in 'cadaveric spasm.
  • Cause of death: Death is due to medullary paralysis or asphyxia due to spasm of respiratory muscles or due to exhaustion from convulsions.

Reference: Review of Forensic medicine and Toxicology, Gautam Biswas, 5th edition, Page No. 630
