questions.text: Familial HNPCC has a defect in?
questions.solution:
• Hereditary nonpolyposis colon carcinoma (HNPCC) Lynch syndrome,syndrome dramatically illustrates the role of DNA repair genes in predisposition to cancer.
  • This disorder, characterized by familial carcinomas of the colon affecting predominantly the cecum and proximal colon, results from defects in genes involved in DNA mismatch repair.
  • When a strand of DNA is being repaired, the products of mismatch repair genes act as "spell checkers." For example, if there is an erroneous pairing of G with T, rather than the normal A with T, the mismatch repair genes correct the defect.
  • Without these "proofreaders," errors accumulate at an increased rate. Mutations in at least four mismatch repair genes have been found to underlie HNPCC.
  • A characteristic finding in the genome of patients with mismatch repair defects is microsatellite instability (MSI).
  • Microsatellites are tandem repeats of one to six nucleotides found throughout the genome. In normal people, the length of these microsatellites remains constant.
  • By contrast, in patients with HNPCC, these satellites are unstable and increase or decrease in length.
  • Although HNPCC accounts for only 2% to 4% of all colonic cancers, MSI can be detected in about 15% of sporadic cancers due to acquired mutations that disrupt the function of mismatched repair genes.

Reference: Robbins basics of pathology, 10th edition, Page- 227

questions.text: A 16 month old child has weight of 8 kg. Look at the growth chart given. Best management will be
questions.solution:
On each growth chart, there are 3 printed growth curves. These are called Reference Lines or Z Score Lines and are used to compare and interpret the growth pattern of the child and assess her/his nutritional status. The 1st top curve line on the growth chart i.e upper border of green band is the median which is, generally speaking, the average. Second line is the junction of green and yellow bands 3rd line is the junction of yellow and orange bands. Weight of all normal and healthy children, when plotted on the growth chart, fall above 2nd curve (green band); weight of moderately underweight children fall below the 2nd curve to 3rd curve (yellow band); and weight of severely underweight children fall below the 3rd curve (orange band).

The currently accepted definitions, set out by the WHO, are as follows:

  • Moderate acute malnutrition (MAM), defined as weight-for-height z-score (WHZ) between -2 and -3 or mid-upper arm circumference (MUAC) between 115 millimeters and <125 millimeters
  • Severe acute malnutrition (SAM), defined as WHZ < -3 or MUAC < 115 millimeters, or the presence of bilateral pitting edema, or both
  • Global acute malnutrition (GAM)refers to MAM and SAM together; it is used as a measurement of nutritional status at a population level and as an indicator of the severity of an emergency situation.

The management of MAM can be broadly categorized into prevention and treatment strategies. In general, because wasting results in a loss of body mass relative to height, the standard practice has been to provide the child with additional energy and nutrient-dense foods to promote weight gain.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fragile X syndrome?
questions.solution:
• Fragile X syndrome is the prototype of diseases in which the causative mutation occurs in a long repeating sequence of three nucleotides.
  • Fragile X syndrome results from a mutation in the FMR1 gene, which maps to Xq27.3 and is the second most common genetic cause of mental retardation, after Down syndrome.
  • It has a frequency of 1 in 1550 for males and 1 in 8000 for females.
  • The syndrome derives its name from the karyotypic appearance of the X chromosome in the original method of diagnosis.
  • Culturing patient cells in a folate-deficient medium typically showed a discontinuity of staining or constriction in the long arm of the X chromosome.
  • This method has now been supplanted by DNA-based analysis of triplet repeat size.
  • Clinically affected males have moderate to severe mental retardation, although the extent of impairment is highly variable. It is not unusual for some children to initially be diagnosed with autism-like symptoms.
  • The typical physical phenotype includes a long face with a large mandible, large everted ears, and large testicles (macroorchidism).
  • Although characteristic of fragile X syndrome, these abnormalities are not always present or may be quite subtle.
  • The only distinctive physical abnormality that can be detected in at least 90% of postpubertal males with fragile X syndrome is macroorchidism.
  • As with all X-linked diseases, fragile X syndrome predominantly affects males.
  • Analysis of several pedigrees, however, shows some patterns of transmission not typically associated with other X-linked recessive disorders. These include the following:
    • Carrier males. Approximately 20% of males who, by pedigree analysis, are known to carry a fragile X mutation do not manifest the typical neurological symptoms or physical characteristics of fragile X during childhood.
    • As discussed below, these carrier males (also known as "transmitting males") harbor a detectable molecular abnormality at the FMR1 locus but not the full-fledged mutation observed in symptomatic children.
    • Affected females. From 30% to 50% of carrier women with the fragile X mutation on one chromosome might show features of mild cognitive impairment or other behavioral disturbances.
    • Approximately 20% develop features of premature reproductive failure. The presence of symptoms in carrier females, albeit mild, is unusual for an X-linked recessive disease.
    • Anticipation. This term refers to the phenomenon whereby clinical features of fragile X syndrome worsen with each successive generation, as if the mutation becomes increasingly deleterious as it is transmitted from a man to his grandsons and great-grandsons.

Reference: Robbins basic pathology, 10th edition, Page- 269

questions.text: A 44-year-old female presents with recurrent uveitis and scleritis. She has a 3-month history of nasal discharge and shortness of breath. The definitive diagnosis is made by confirming the presence of noncaseating granulomas on biopsy. Serological tests include the presence of antineutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (c-ANCA), which have a sensitivity of about 60–88%. Antibodies to proteinase 3 (PR-3) are highly sensitive in active WG (90%). Other features of WG include subglottic stenosis, pauciimmune glomerulonephritis, mononeuritis multiplex, and arthritis. In this patient other causes of cavitatory lung lesions such as infection need to be excluded prior to treatment

questions.text: Patient was on an antiarrhythmic drug and developed hypothyroidism and pulmonary fibrosis. Which antiarrhythmic may cause it
questions.solution:
Amiodarone is the longest acting (t1/2 = 3-8 weeks) anti-arrhythmic drug. It possesses action of all classes of antiarrhythmic drugs (Na+ channel blockade non-competitive, β blockade, K+ channel blockade and Ca2+ channel blockade).

Due to this property, it has the widest antiarrhythmic spectrum. It carries less chances of causing torsades despite prolongation of QT interval. It contains iodine (approx. 37.5%) and can result in hyperthyroidism (similar drug dronedarone does not contain iodine).

It can also cause hypothyroidism by inhibiting peripheral conversion of T4 to T3. Other adverse effects include peripheral neuropathy, myocardial depression, pulmonary fibrosis,hepatotoxicity, corneal microdeposits and photosensitivity.

questions.text: During harvest season, a farmer was taking rest in shade. He felt something biting and woke up to see it moving away quickly. He felt drowsy, pain and uncontrolled bleeding from the wound site. The wound became red with blisters. Which of the following was the possible cause?
questions.solution:
Above features is highly suggestive of viper bite.

Types of venom:

  1. Neurotoxic - Cobra, krait
  2. Hemotoxic - Vipers
  3. Myotoxic - Sea snakes

FEATURES OF VIPER BITE

  • The viperine venom is mainly haemolytic and causes intravascular haemolysis and depression of the coagulation mechanism.
  • The area around the bite is red and painful. The onset of swelling starts within fifteen minutes and there is often blood-stained discharge from the wound. Persistent bleeding from bite site is a constant feature. Blisters begin to appear in about 12 hours in and around the bite site, progressing subsequently to involve the entire limb.
  • Haematuria may be seen within a few hours of the bite. Prominent features are shock and haemorrhage.
  • In about 10 to 15% of the cases, extensive necrosis of skin, subcutaneous tissues and muscles may occur followed by epistaxis, haemoptysis, ecchymoses, intracranial and subconjunctival haemorrhages, and bleeding into the floor of the mouth, tympanic membrane, gastrointestinal and genitourinary tract, retroperitoneum and intraperitoneum. In severe cases, the main feature is the persisting shock.
  • Bleeding and clotting time are usually prolonged. A haemorrhagic syndrome with blood-stained sputum, haemorrhages from the gums, rectum, the site of bite, etc., occur due to the increased coagulation time. Intravascular haemolysis may lead to haemoglobinuria.
  • In the case of Russell's viper and hump-nosed viper, renal failure is a frequent complication. Petechial haemorrhages are common. Death is usually due haemorrhage.

FEATURES OF COBRA BITE

  • Local symptoms start within 6 to 8 minutes. A small reddish wheal develops at the site of bite. The bitten area is tender with slight radiating burning pain and oozing of bloodstained fluid. Swelling may be minimal or even absent.
  • The patient feels sleepy, slightly intoxicated, weakness of legs and is reluctant to stand or move. Ptosis is the earliest neuroparalytic manifestation followed by ophthalmoplegia. There may be extraocular muscle weakness and strabismus.
  • Weakness of the muscles increases and develops into paralysis of the lower limbs. The paralysis then spreads to the trunk and affects the head which falls forward. The eyelids also hang down. After half to one hour, there is excessive salivation and even vomiting, headache, vertigo, paraesthesia around the mouth and myalgia. This is followed by paralysis of the facial muscles, palate, jaws, tongue, vocal cords, neck muscles. Muscles of deglutition become progressively flaccidly paralysed due to which there is difficulty in speech and swallowing. After about two hours, the paralysis is complete.
  • Respiratory arrest may occur due to obstruction of upper airway by the paralysed tongue or inhaled vomitus or due to paralysis of intercostal muscles and diaphragm. Coma sets in and finally the respirations stop with or without convulsions and the heart stops.

FEATURES OF KRAIT BITE

  • Symptoms resemble those of cobra bite, but there is no swelling or burning pain at the site of the bite and the convulsions are milder, while the feeling of drowsiness and intoxication is more intense. Albumin appears in urine.

FEATURES OF SCORPION STING

  • This venom contains neurotoxins that cause sodium channels to remain open. Such envenomation usually are associated with little swelling, but prominent pain, paraesthesia and hyperesthesia can be accentuated by tapping on the affected area (the tap test).
  • These symptoms soon spread to other locations; dysfunction of cranial nerves and hyperexcitability of skeletal muscles develop within hours. Patients present with restlessness, blurred vision, abnormal eye movements, profuse salivation, lacrimation, rhinorrhea, slurred speech, difficulty in handling secretions, diaphoresis, nausea, and vomiting. Muscle twitching, jerking and shaking may be mistaken for a seizure.
  • Complications include tachycardia, arrhythmias, hypertension, hyperthermia, rhabdomyolysis, and acidosis. Fatal respiratory arrest is most common among young children and the elderly.

FEATURES OF WASP BITE

  • Wasp venom is composed of biogenic amines like histamine, serotonin, acetylcholine, enzymes like Phospholipase A and B, hyaluronidase, toxic peptides etc.
  • Clinical Features: Local- Pain, redness, swelling
  • Systemic: Person allergic to venom may develop anaphylaxis - Tingling sensation, flushing, dizziness, syncope, vomiting and diarrhoea, wheezing, urticaria, angioedema, renal failure, haemolysis with haemoglobinuria, rhabdomyolysis etc.

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 427

questions.text: What is the sequence of vitamin D synthesis
questions.solution:
• Vitamin D is synthesized in the skin & then metabolized to the active metabolite, calcitriol, in liver & kidney. So correct sequence of vitamin D synthesis & metabolism is Skin → Liver → Kidney (Option A)
  • 7-Dehydrocholesterol (an intermediate in the synthesis of cholesterol that accumulates in the skin) undergoes a non enzymic reaction on exposure to ultraviolet light, yielding previtamin D.
  • This undergoes a further reaction over a period of hours to form cholecalciferol, which is absorbed into the bloodstream.
  • In temperate climates, the plasma concentration of vitamin D is highest at the end of summer and lowest at the end of winter. Beyond latitudes about 40° north or south, there is very little ultraviolet radiation of the appropriate wavelength in winter.
  • Cholecalciferol, either synthesized in the skin or from food, undergoes two hydroxylations to yield the active metabolite, 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D or calcitriol. Ergocalciferol from fortified foods undergoes similar hydroxylation yield calcitriol.
  • In the liver, cholecalciferol is hydroxylated to form the 25-hydroxy derivative, calcidiol. This is released into the circulation bound to a vitamin D-binding globulin, which is the main storage form of the vitamin. In the kidney, calcidiol undergoes either 1-hydroxylation to yield the active metabolite 1,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (calcitriol), or 24-hydroxylation to yield a probably inactive metabolite, 24,25-dihydroxyvitamin D (24-hydroxy calcidiol).
  • Some tissues, other than those that are involved in calcium homeostasis, take up calcidiol from the circulation and synthesize calcitriol that acts within that cell
  • So Option A is the correct option.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry 31st edition, Chapter 44, Page 531

questions.text: An open thoracotomy is performed in a patient presented with chest trauma. under which category would this wound be classified?
questions.solution:
Classification of wounds- clean wound, clean contaminated wound, contaminated wound and dirty wound.

Clean wound examples- hernia, thyroid and breast surgeries

Clean contaminated wound where a cavity is to be opened. Example- GJ

Contaminated wound example- elective colorectal anastomosis, perforation cases, Open cardiac massage, open thoracotomy

Reference: Schwartz page 169

Class 1:

Clean wounds include those in which no infection is present, only skin microflora potentially contaminate the wound, and no hollow viscus that contains microbes is entered.

Class 1 D wounds are similar, except that a prosthetic device (example; mesh or valve) is inserted.

Class 2:

Clean contaminated wounds (class II) include those in which a hollow viscus such as the respiratory, alimentary or genitourinary tracts with indigenous bacterial flora is opened under controlled circumstances without significant spillage of contents.

Class 3:

While elective colorectal cases have classically been included as class II cases, a number of studies in the last decade have documented higher SSI rates (9-25%).

Infection is also more common in cases involving entry into the rectal space

Contaminated wounds (class III) include open accidental wounds encountered early after injury, those with extensive introduction of bacteria into a normally sterile area of the body due to major breaks in sterile technique (example- open cardiac massage), gross spillage of viscus contents such as from the intestine, or incision through inflamed albeit non purulent tissue.

Dirty wounds (class IV) include dramatic wounds in which a significant delay in treatment has occurred and in which necrotic tissue is present, those created in the presence of overt infection as evidenced by the presence of purulent material and those created to access a perforated viscus accompanied by a high degree of contamination.

questions.text: C wave in JVP is due to which of the following?
questions.solution:
a wave represents atrial systole, occurs along with S4, preceding theS1. a wave will be hence absent in atrial fibrillation. A prominent a wave will be seen when the atria contracts against a non compliant right ventricle. Canon a wave occurs in AV dissociation, where the atria contracts against a closed ventricle, as ion Ventricular tachycardia.

X decent indicates a fall in the right atrial pressure, after the atrial systole. During this time, the tricuspid valves close and the valve is pushed into the atria, resulting in a small positive c wave, which interrupts the x decent. Hence it correlated with S1.

Immediately after the closure of the tricuspid valve, the ventricular systole begins, during which time, the atria is relaxed and the atrial filling takes place.

The atrial filling is represented by the v wave in JVP. When the filling of the atria is increased the v wave will be accentuated. In tricuspid regurgitation, the tricuspid valves fail to close properly hence the c wave will merge with the v wave to form gaint v wave or the v wave is vetricularized.

They decent indicates the rapid filling of the ventricles. In tricuspid regurgitation, the y decent will be rapid. In conditions where the RV compliance is reduced or the tricuspid valve is stenosed, the y decent will be prolonged.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a clinical feature of Ramsay hunt syndrome?
questions.solution:
Treatment of Ramsay Hunt syndrome can ease pain and decrease the risk of long-term complications. Medications include:

  • Antiviral drugs. Medications such as acyclovir (Zovirax), famciclovir (Famvir) or valacyclovir (Valtrex) often help combat the chickenpox virus.
  • Corticosteroids. A short regimen of high-dose prednisone appears to boost the effect of antiviral drugs in Ramsay Hunt syndrome.
  • Anti-anxiety medications. Drugs such as diazepam (Valium) can help relieve vertigo.
  • Pain relievers. The pain associated with Ramsay Hunt syndrome can be severe. Prescription pain medications may be needed.

questions.text: A child presents with dermatitis, thinning of hair and alopecia. The family reports a long history of consuming raw egg whites. Which vitamin deficiency is most likely responsible for these symptoms?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Vitamin A deficiency is the most important preventable cause of blindness. The earliest sign of deficiency is a loss of sensitivity to green light, followed by impairment to adapt to dim light, then night blindness, an inability to see in the dark. 
  • More prolonged deficiency leads to xerophthalmia: keratinization of the cornea and blindness.
  • Vitamin A also has an important role in differentiation of immune system cells, and even mild deficiency leads to increased susceptibility to infectious diseases.
  • The synthesis of retinol-binding protein, which is required to transport the vitamin in the bloodstream, is reduced in response to infection(it is a negative acute phase protein), decreasing the circulating concentration of the vitamin and further impairing immune responses.
  • Option B: Pernicious anemia arises when vitamin B12 deficiency impairs the metabolism of folic acid, leading to functional folate deficiency that disturbs erythropoiesis, causing immature precursors of erythrocytes to be released into the circulation(megaloblastic anemia).
  • The most common cause of pernicious anemia is failure of the absorption of vitamin B12 rather than dietary deficiency.
  • This can be the result of failure of intrinsic factor secretion caused by autoimmune disease affecting parietal cells or from production of anti-intrinsic factor antibodies.
  • There is irreversible degeneration of the spinal cord in pernicious anemia, as a result of failure of methylation of one arginine residue in myelin basic protein. This occurs as a result of methionine deficiency in the central nervous system, rather than secondary folate deficiency.
  • Although it is synthesized exclusively by microorganisms, for practical purposes vitamin B12 is found only in foods of animal origin, there being no plant sources of this vitamin. This means that strict vegetarians(vegans) are at risk of developing B12 deficiency. 
  • Option C: Biotin is widely distributed in many foods as biocytin(ε-amino-biotinyl lysine), which is released on proteolysis. It is synthesized by intestinal flora in excess of requirements.
  • Deficiency is unknown, except among people maintained for many months on total parenteral nutrition and a very small number who eat abnormally large amounts of uncooked egg white, which contains avidin, a protein that binds biotin and renders it unavailable for absorption.
  • Biotin deficiency may lead to thinning of hair with progression to loss of hair(alopecia) & dermatitis.
  • Option D: Iron deficiency may lead to microcytic anemia, may affect hair like hair loss and alopecia.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 31st edition page no- 1317

questions.text: A 35 year old female on OCPS presents with intermittent abdominal pain and intermittent diarrhea. Appearance of the intestine is as in the image given below. Endoscopy showed ileum involvement with rectal sparing. Which of the following is specific to a given disease?
questions.solution:
• Figure shows Gross pathology of Crohn disease. (A) Small-intestinal stricture. (B) Linear mucosal ulcers and thickened intestinal wall. (C) Creeping fat.
  • Inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) is a chronic condition resulting from complex interactions between intestinal microbiota and host immunity in genetically predisposed individuals resulting in inappropriate mucosal immune activation.
  • IBD encompasses two entities, Crohn disease and ulcerative colitis. The distinction between ulcerative colitis and Crohn disease is based, in large part, on the distribution of affected sites and the morphologic expression of disease at those sites.

questions.text: A child presented with refractory anemia. Below is provided the smear of bone marrow biopsy of the child. The probable enzyme deficiency is

  • Option B: Lysosomal α1 → 4 and α1 → 6 glucosidase(acid maltase) deficiency can lead to Pompe disease. It is glycogen storage disease which is characterized by accumulation of glycogen in lysosomes: juvenile-onset variant, muscle hypotonia, death from heart failure by age 2; adult-onset variant, muscle dystrophy.
  • Option C: Hexosaminidase A deficiency can lead to Tay sach disease, characterized by mental retardation, blindness, muscular weakness.
  • Option D: Hexosaminidase B deficiency can lead to Sandhoff’s disease.

Reference: Harper's illustrated biochemistry, 31st edition, Chapter 24, Page 235

A patient with asthma and hyperthyroidism, not currently on any asthmatic medications, presents with anxiety and restlessness. His vitals are Heart rate of 120/min and BP of 180/110 mmHg. ECG shows atrial fibrillation. What is the most appropriate treatment in this case?
questions.solution:
Thyroid storm (thyrotoxic crisis):

This is an emergency due to decompensated hyperthyroidism.

Vigorous treatment with the following is indicated:

Nonselective β blockers (e.g. propranolol) are the most valuable measure.

  • Propylthiouracil reduces hormone synthesis as well as peripheral T4 to T3 conversion.
  • Iopanoic acid

They are potent inhibitors of thyroid hormone releasefrom thyroid, as well as peripheral T4 to T3 conversion.

  • Corticosteroids
  • Diltiazem 60–120 mg BD oral may be added if tachycardia is not controlled by propranolol alone, or when it is contraindicated.
  • Rehydration, anxiolytics, external cooling and appropriate antibiotics are the other measures.

Reference: K D Tripathi 8th edition page 278

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with claudication in forearm, transient loss of vision and abdominal pain. She also had weak femoral pulses. Fundus also showed retinal haemorrhages. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
In this question, we have a young female with symptoms of upper limb claudication, visual loss, abdominal pain and weak femoral pulses. The history points to the involvement of the branches of Aorta. The retinal hemorrhage could be secondary to hypertension. The involvement of large and medium vessels in a young female points towards the diagnosis of Takayasu Arteritis.

PAN typically involves renal and visceral vessels, ie, small and medium sized arteries. It does not produce absent peripheral pulses.

Microscopic polyangiitis is a small vessel vasculitis, mainly presenting as glomerulonephritis and pulmonary vasculitis.

Thromboangiitis obliterans (Buerger's disease) is an inflammatory occlusive vascular disorder of small and medium sized arteries of the distal upper and lower limb and is seen in men <40 years. Although the disease presents with claudication, larger pulses like brachial will be preserved and radial pulses will be absent.

questions.text: A dead body is brought with ligature mark over neck, which is encircling the neck, transverse, below the thyroid cartilage. No salivary dribbling noted. This condition is
questions.solution:
Ligature mark:

  • Caused as a result of pressure of the ligature over the skin. It is a Pressure abrasion
  • It is a well-defined groove or furrow, which is slightly depressed and of same width as that of ligature material. Groove may be narrow at parts due to folding of ligature.

Ligature mark in strangulation: Usually situated at the level of thyroid cartilage or below. Usually situated transversely (Rarely oblique) & completely encircle the neck.

Ligature mark in hanging: Usually Oblique. In ≈ 80% of cases, it is situated above the level of thyroid cartilage, in ≈ 15% of cases over the thyroid cartilage and in ≈ 5% of case below the level of thyroid cartilage.

Throttling or Manual strangulation: It is a form of strangulation in which neck is constricted by using hand/hands.

Mugging: The term strictly means throttling by pressure from an arm held around the throat. The attack is usually made from behind, the neck being trapped in the crook of the elbow. Pressure is then exerted either on the front of the larynx (Air choke or Bar arm control) or at one or both sides by the forearm and upper arm (Blood choke or Carotid sleeper hold).

Reference: The Essentials of Forensic Medicine & Toxicology, KS Narayan Reddy, 35th edition, Page No. 262, 263

questions.text: A patient has multiple tendon xanthomas. Serum cholesterol(398 mg/dl) & LDL (220 mg/dl) were found to be raised. Statins were given to this patient. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Option A: Familial lipoprotein lipase deficiency(type I) leading to hypertriacylglycerolemia due to deficiency of LPL, abnormal LPL or apo C-ll deficiency causing inactive LPL. Slow clearance of chylomicrons and VLDL. Low levels of LDL and HDL. No increased risk of coronary disease
  • Option B: Familial hypercholesterolemia(type IIa) occurs due to defective LDL receptors or mutation in ligand region of apo B-100. Elevated LDL levels and hypercholesterolemia, resulting in atherosclerosis and coronary disease.
  • Option C: Familial α-lipoprotein deficiency, Tangier disease, Fish-eye disease, Apo A-I deficiencies: All have low or near absence of HDL. Tendency toward hypertriacylglycerolemia as a result of absence of apo C-ll, causing inactive LPL. Low LDL levels. Atherosclerosis in the elderly.
  • Option D: Huntington's disease is a rare, inherited disease that causes the progressive breakdown of nerve cells in the brain. Not a disorder related to lipoproteins.

Reference: Harper’s illustrated biochemistry, 31st edition, Chapter 26, Page 258

questions.text: A 66-year-old male was seen with a history of recurrent oral ulceration. He has no other symptoms. Past medical history includes posterior uveitis and aseptic meningitis. On examination he has painful eythematous lesions on the anterior shins. Lab evaluation reveals a mild normocytic anemia. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution: • This is a case of Behcet’s syndrome complicated by erythema nodosum. This is a condition more commonly seen in people who live on the Silk route from the Mediterranean basin to China. There is a strong association with HLA B51. The disease is characterized by thrombophlebitis, recurrent orogenital apthous ulceration, posterior uveitis, and meningoencephalitis. Cutaneous findings include a positive pathergy test, pseudofolliculitis, or erythema nodosum. Rarely pulmonary artery aneurysms can occur.

questions.text: A patient presented with a history of multiple episodes of vomiting. He was given an intravenous drug and later he developed abnormal movement. Which of the following drugs can be used to treat this condition?
questions.solution:
Central anticholinergics

These are drugs having a higher central : peripheral anticholinergic action ratio than atropine, but the pharmacological profile is similar.

The central anticholinergics act by reducing the unbalanced cholinergic activity in the striatumof parkinsonian patients.

These drugs produce 10-25% improvement in parkinsonian symptoms lasting 4-8 hours after a single dose. Generally,tremor is benefited more than rigidity; hypokinesiais improved the least. Sialorrhoea is controlled by their peripheral action.

Anticholinergics are the only drugs effective in drug (phenothiazines, other D2 antagonists) induced parkinsonism.

The side effect profile is similar to atropine. Impairment of memory and cognition, organic confusional states and blurred vision are more common in the elderly. Urinary retention is possible in elderly males.

Reference: K D Tripathi 8th edition page 460

The next best test would be DEC Provocation Test- A small dose of diethyl carbamazine (2 mg per kg body weight) induces microfilariae to appear in peripheral blood even during day time. Microfilaria may be demonstrated in centrifuged deposits of lymph, chylous urine or other appropriate specimens. Adult filarial worms can be seen in sections of biopsied lymph nodes, but this is not employed in routine diagnosis.

Knowing which species of filarial parasites wont make any change in the treatment plan. As the DOC for filariasis is di- ethyl carbamazine.

questions.text: An alcoholic patient presented to OPD with ataxia, confusion and visual changes. Identify the cause of disease?
questions.solution:
Wernicke-Korsakoff (WK) syndrome is a serious brain condition that is usually, but not exclusively, associated with chronic alcohol misuse and severe alcohol use disorder (AUD)

WK syndrome involves two different brain disorders that often occur together: Wernicke's disease and Korsakoff's psychosis. They result from brain damage associated with AUD, combined with vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency. In people with severe AUD, poor nutrition decreases the ability of the gut to absorb thiamine from food and, therefore, increases the chance of developing WK syndrome. Without treatment, WK syndrome can be disabling, produce permanent memory loss, and be life-threatening.

questions.solution: Bell's Palsy typically causes sudden weakness in the muscles on one side of the face. The weakness makes half of the face appear to droop, and smiles become one-sided. Additionally, the eye on the affected side may be hard to close. Specifically, the angle of the mouth deviates toward the opposite side of the affected facial weakness. So, if the right side of the face is affected, the angle of the mouth would deviate toward the left side.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about clinical trials is true?
questions.solution:
Clinical trials are conducted in sequential phases, each with its own specific objectives and methods12. The phases are as follows:

Phase I: These trials evaluate the safety, determining the effects of a treatment on a small group of participants (20-80) and defining the maximum tolerable dose.

Phase II: Building on Phase I, these trials further assess safety and evaluate efficacy on a larger group (100-300) while continuing to determine the best dosage and administration method.

Phase III: These trials involve larger groups of participants (1000-3000) and are designed to confirm efficacy, monitor side effects, and compare the new treatment to standard treatments.

Phase IV: These trials are conducted after the treatment has been approved and are designed to monitor long-term safety and effectiveness

questions.text: A patient presented with multiple warty sessile lesions. What is the diagnosis ?
questions.solution:
• Anogenital warts / condyloma acuminatum. Anogenital warts are common and are caused in 75% by HPV-6.
  • The remainder are caused by HPV-11
  • They are often asymptomatic, but may cause discomfort, discharge or bleeding.
  • The typical anogenital wart is soft, pink, elongated and sometimes filiform or pedunculated. The lesions are usually multiple especially on moist surfaces, and their growth can be enhanced during pregnancy. The commonest sites, the area of frenulum, corona and glans in men, and the posterior fourchette in women, correspond to the likely sites of greatest coital friction.
  • Imiquimod 5% cream is an immunomodulator, TLR 7 agonist, used in treatment of warts
  • In pregnancy, use cryotherapy or TCA application

questions.text: Fracture at which point leads to loss of dorsiflexion of foot in
questions.solution:
• Common peroneal nerve:
  • It is the smaller terminal branch of the sciatic nerve.
  • It extends from the superior angle of the popliteal fossa to the lateral angle, along the medial border of the biceps femoris.
  • Continuing downwards and forwards, it winds around the posterolateral aspect of the neck of the fibula, pierces the peroneus longus, and divides into the superficial and deep peroneal nerves.
  • The common peroneal nerve can be palpated against the posterolateral side of the neck of the fibula.
  • It may be injured in this area.
  • It is the most frequently injured nerve in the lower limb.
  • This nerve is relatively unprotected.
  • It may get entrapped between the attachments of peroneus longus to the head and shaft of the fibula.
  • Patients present 'foot drop' which is usually painless.
  • There is loss of dorsiflexion of ankle and weakness of eversion of the foot.

Reference: Textbook of B. D. Chaurasia, Volume-2, 8th Edition, Page No - 92, 93, 198

questions.text: Ribbon candy appearance on immunofluorescence is seen in ?
questions.solution:
• Bullous pemphigoid is another distinctive acquired blistering disorder with an autoimmune basis.
  • Blistering in bullous pemphigoid is triggered by the linear deposition of autoreactive IgG antibodies and complement in the epidermal basement membrane.
  • Reactivity also occurs in the basement membrane attachment plaques (hemidesmosomes), where most bullous pemphigoid antigen (most commonly type XVII collagen) is located. The proteins that are recognized by the autoantibodies have structural roles in dermoepidermal adhesion. IgG autoantibodies to hemidesmosome components fix complement and cause tissue injury by recruiting neutrophils and eosinophils.
  • Deposition of IgG antibody (detected by direct immunofluorescence) in the subepidermal basement membrane (epidermis is on the left side of the fluorescent band).

Reference: Robbins, 10th edition Page- 898

questions.text: In a 35 year old patient, due to intravascular hemolysis, serum K+ increased to 5.5mEq/L. What will happen to resting membrane potential in this patient
questions.solution:
Resting membrane potential is primarily determined by the concentration gradient of K⁺ across the cell membrane. Under normal conditions, K⁺ is more concentrated inside the cell compared to the outside, which contributes to the negative resting potential. If the extracellular concentration of K⁺ increases, this gradient is reduced.

As the concentration of K⁺ outside the cell increases (from 4 mEq/L to 5.5 mEq/L in this case), the driving force for K⁺ to leave the cell decreases, and the resting membrane potential becomes less negative, i.e., more positive.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Edition Page no- 65

questions.text: A 2 year old child presents with recurrent fever and infections. On testing , serum contains normal or elevated levels of IgM but no IgA or IgE and extremely low levels of IgG. What is false about this condition
questions.solution:
Absence of CD40L on T cells is the most common defect . Approximately 70% of individuals with hyper-IgM syndrome have the X-linked form of the disease, caused by mutations in the gene encoding

CD40L located on Xq26 that interfere with CD4+ helper T cell function. The serum of persons with this syndrome contains normal or elevated levels of IgM but no IgA or IgE and extremely low levels of IgG. Those with CD40L mutations are susceptible to pneumonia caused by the intracellular organism Pneumocystis jirovecii because CD40L-mediated macrophage activation, a key reaction of cell-mediated immunity, is also defective. Occasionally, the IgM antibodies react with blood cells, giving rise to autoimmune hemolytic anemia, thrombocytopenia, and neutropenia.

Reference: robbins 10th ed,pg 245

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman presented with fever, migratory arthritis of lower large joints and tachycardia. On auscultation a pansystolic murmur is noticed. Echo cardiography shows Mitral Regurgitation. What is the Biopsy finding shown below?
questions.solution:
• The cardiac manifestations of Rheumatic fever are in the form of focal inflammatory involvement of the interstitial tissue of all the three layers of the heart, the so-called pancarditis.
  • The pathognomonic feature of pancarditis in RF is the presence of distinctive Aschoff nodules or Aschoff bodies.

THE ASCHOFF NODULES OR BODIES:

  • The Aschoff nodules or the Aschoff bodies are spheroidal or fusiform distinct tiny structures, 1-2 mm in size, occurring in the interstitium of the heart in RF and may be visible to naked eye.
  • They are especially found in the vicinity of small blood vessels in the myocardium and endocardium and occasionally in the pericardium and the adventitia of the proximal part of the aorta.
  • Lesions similar to the Aschoff nodules may be found in the extracardiac tissues.


An Aschoff body (granulomatous stage) in the myocardium. Inbox shows Anitschkow cell in longitudinal section (LS) with caterpillar-like serrated nuclear chromatin, while cross section (CS) shows owl-eye appearance of central chromatin mass and perinuclear halo.

Reference: Harshmohan textbook of pathology, 7th edition, Page- 420

questions.text: The mechanism of bacterial resistance to penicillins via beta lactamase is by

Beta Lactamase is an enzyme produced by bacteria which will break the penicillin ring resulting inhibiting the action of penicillin on the cell wall thus causing the bacterial resistance.

Penicillin has the ring structure in it(hexagonal structure)

Altered penicillin binding protein is not the mechanism of bacterial resistance to penicillin via beta lactamase.

Drug efflux is not the mechanism of bacterial resistance to penicillin via beta lactamase

Alteration in 50s ribosome is not the mechanism of bacterial resistance to penicillin via beta lactamase

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker Textbook of Microbiology 10th Edition, page 202

questions.text: Ravibabu is a 74-year-old construction worker was scheduled to undergo elective hip replacement. During pre-op evaluation, his chest xray showed following findings. He reports no previous respiratory problems. What is the finding called?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray demonstrates extensive pleural plaques. These are evident both above the hemi- diaphragms and also along the ribs throughout the thorax. This is a benign condition and rarely causes symptoms. The plaques occur after a latent period of approximately 20-40 years following asbestos exposure and almost exclusively involve the parietal pleura.

The X-ray appearance in extensive pleural plaques is also called Holly Leaf Sign.

questions.text: A known hypertensive young female planning for pregnancy came for preconceptional counselling. She is compliant to hypertensive drugs. Which of the following drugs will you advise to stop?
questions.solution:
Adverse effects

The adverse effect profile of all ACE inhibitors is similar.

  • Hypotension: an initial sharp fall in BP occurs especially in diuretic treated and CHF patients; persistent hypotension may be troublesome in MI patients.
  • Hyperkalaemia: This is likely in patients with impaired renal function and in those taking K+ sparing diuretics, NSAIDs or β blockers.
  • Cough: a persistent brassy cough occurs in 10-16% patients within 1-8 weeks, appears to be caused by inhibition of bradykinin/substance P breakdown in the lungs of susceptible individuals.
  • Rashes, urticaria: occur in 1-4% recipients;
  • Dysgeusia: reversible loss or alteration of taste sensation due to captopril occurs in few patients, rarely with other ACE inhibitors.
  • Foetopathic: fetal growth retardation, hypoplasia of organs and fetal death may occur if ACE inhibitors are given during the later half of pregnancy.
  • Headache, dizziness, nausea and bowel upset:
  • Granulocytopenia and proteinuria: These are rare, but warrant withdrawal.
  • Acute renal failure: It may be precipitated by ACE inhibitors in patients with bilateral renal artery stenosis due to fall in glomerular filtration pressure.

Reference: K D Tripathi 8th edition page 531

questions.text: An 8 year old boy presents with generalized edema pallor and hyperlipidemia. His serum cholesterol is 238 mg/dl, urine protein is 3+ and urine microscopy revealed oval fat bodies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• Nephrotic range proteinuria is defined as proteinuria >3.5 g/24 hour or a urine protein : creatinine ratio >2.
  • The triad of clinical findings associated with nephrotic syndrome arising from the large urinary losses of protein are hypoalbuminemia (≤2.5 g/dL), edema, and hyperlipidemia (cholesterol >200 mg/dL).

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with memory loss over the last several months. He reports Joint pains, low-grade fevers, skin hyperpigmentation, and frequent diarrhea. On examination, he has mild rigidity in his upper extremities, concurrent slow pendular movements of the eyes and contraction of the masseter. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Whipple disease is caused by an infection with Tropheryma whippelii, leading to low-grade fevers, arthralgia, diarrhea, muscle wasting, and hyperpigmentation. Neurological symptoms include extrapyramidal symptoms, limitations of vertical gaze, and characteristic oculomasticatory myorhythmia (pendular oscillations of the eyes with rhythmic contractions of the masticatory muscles). Wilson disease is an autosomal-recessive disorder resulting in accumulation of copper resulting in liver disease, movement disorders, and dementia. Fever and oculomasticatory myorhythmia are not present in Wilson disease. Neurosyphilis causes psychosis, agitation, aggression, dementia, multiple cranial neuropathies, and multifocal vasculitic infarcts.

questions.text: A pregnant woman, whose niece contracted varicella in the same house was negative for serum antibodies for varicella, this would mean?
questions.solution:
Chicken pox is caused by varicella zoster virus

Incubation period is 10-21 days

Infection is acquired through the respiratory tract via air droplets or rarely from conjunctiva. Infectious period(Communicable period) for chicken pox is 2 days prior to 5 days after onset of rash with a very high secondary attack rate of 90%.

Clinical feature has two stage

  1. Pre eruptive stage - characterized by fever, back pain, malaise and shivering
  2. Eruptive phase - Has characteristic rash with following feature

Superficial and unilocular(Rash of smallpox is deep seated and multilocular)

Symmetrical, mostly on flexor surface(Rash of small pox usually affect extensor surface)

Centripetal distribution - (Rash of smallpox has centrifugal distribution)

Affect axilla but spares palm and sole - (smallpox affect palms and soles but spares axilla)

Pleomorphic with appearance of all stages of rash simultaneously(Rash is non isomorphic in nature in small pox)

Dew drop on rose petal appearance(Rash of smallpox has umbilicated appearance)

Area of inflammation around the rash(In small pox there is no inflammation around the rash)

Evolution of rash is rapid, scabs begin to form 4-7 days after rash(Evolution is slow, scab begin 10-14 after rash in smallpox)

Reference: Ananthanarayan and Paniker Textbook of Microbiology 10th Edition, page 477

questions.text: Last ligament to be punctured during lumbar puncture
questions.solution:
• The arachnoid and pia mater are separated by subarachnoid space which contains cerebrospinal fluid.
  • The medical procedure known as a lumbar puncture or spinal tap involves use of a needle to withdraw cerebrospinal fluid from the subarachnoid space, usually from the lumbar region of the spine.
  • Layers penetrated:
    • Skin
    • Superficial fascia
    • Supraspinous ligament
    • Interspinous ligament
    • Ligamentum flavum
    • Areolar tissue
    • Dura mater
    • Arachnoid mater

questions.text: This 68 year old male presented with progressive dementia over 6 months and myoclonic jerks of 1 month duration. What is the diagnosis ?

questions.text: A male child is found to have Flexner Wintersteiner rosettes on histopathology. His eye examination reveals white reflex. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
• This is the most common malignant ocular tumor in children.
  • It may be present at birth or recognised in early childhood before the age of 4 years.
  • Retinoblastoma has some peculiar features. About 60% cases of retinoblastoma are sporadic and the remaining 40% are familial.
  • Familial tumours are often multiple and multifocal and transmitted as an autosomal dominant trait by retinoblastoma susceptibility gene (RB) located on chromosome 13.
  • Such individuals have a higher incidence of bilateral tumours and have increased risk of developing second primary tumour, particularly osteogenic sarcoma.
  • Retinoblastoma may occur as a congenital tumour too. Clinically, the child presents with leukocoria i.e. white pupillary reflex.

MORPHOLOGIC FEATURES

  • Grossly, the tumour characteristically appears as a white mass within the retina which may be partly solid and partly necrotic.
  • The tumour may be endophytic when it protrudes into the vitreous, or exophytic when it grows between the retina and the pigment epithelium.
  • Microscopically, the tumour is composed of undifferentiated retinal cells with a tendency towards formation of photoreceptor elements.
  • In the better differentiated area, the tumour cells are characteristically arranged in rosettes.
  • The rosettes may be of 2 types-Flexner-Wintersteiner rosettes characterised by small tumour cells arranged around a lumen with their nuclei away from the lumen, and Homer Wright rosettes having radial arrangement of tumour cells around the central neurofibrillar structure.
  • The tumour shows wide areas of necrosis and calcification and dissemination in all directions-into the vitreous, under the retina, into the optic nerve and even into the brain.

Reference: Harshmohan textbook of pathology, 7th edition, Page- 493

questions.text: A man had GI fluid loss for which he was being given oral rehydration solution. Glucose absorption from his gut will utilize which of the following transporters?
questions.solution:
Glucose entry in all cells in the body occurs by Facilitated diffusion utilizing GLUT except in GIT and KIDNEY

Secondary active transport utilizing SGLT, SGLT-1 in GUT SGLT-2,3 found in renal tubules.

Glucose enters gut the SGLT but leaves gut and enters blood using GLUT.

DEFECT in SGLT-1 causes Glucose and Galactose Malabsorption Syndrome.

Reference: Guyton and Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology 14th Edition, page no- 830

questions.text: Which drug reduces the production of uric acid ?

A 73 year old man presents to the OPD with chronic bleeding per rectum. Which of the following tests is used for confirmation?
1. CA 19-9
2. CECT
3. CEA
4. Colonoscopy + CECT
questions.solution:
Causes for bleeding chronic bleeding per rectum- haemorrhoids, fissure, malignancy, ulcerative colitis, diverticulosis etc.

The gold standard investigation for bleeding per rectum is colonoscopy.

Other investigation that can be done is CT abdomen

CEA is a tumour marker for colonic cancer.

CA 19-9 is a tumour marker for pancreatic cancer.

questions.text: Correct statement regarding cystometrogram?
questions.solution:
The Image is a Cystometrogram.

Segment 1a represents a slight rise in pressure when the first increment in volume is produced.

Segment 1b long and Nearby Flat Segment as further increments are produced and is a true reflection of Laplace Law.

Segment II - A sharp rise in pressure as the micturition reflex is triggered.

Dotted lines represent micturition reflex.

questions.text: A 10-year-old child presents with edema, and massive proteinuria. A diagnosis of minimal change disease was made. Which of the following statements is true about this condition?
questions.solution:
• The child in the case has Nephrotic syndrome characterised by selective proteinuria of albumin.
  • It is more common in the paediatric population. Minimal change disease is the most common type in children.
  • Light microscopy is normal in minimal change disease. Electron microscopy will show effacements of podocytes.
  • It shows excellent response to oral prednisolone.

questions.text: Which of the following is an indicator for poor prognosis in a case of multiple myeloma?
questions.solution:
The single most powerful predictor of survival is β2 microglobulin. It can substitute for staging.

S albumin and β2 microglobulin alone are used for staging Myeloma known as the International Staging System(ISS) and has replaced the Durie salmon staging.

INTERNATIONAL STAGING SYSTEM


28% of patients present in stage I, 39% in stage II and 33% in stage III

Other poor prognostic factors in myeloma are- High labelling index, circulating plasma cells, poor performance status and high LDH levels.

Chromosomal anomalies and Risk stratification:

No aneuploidy in karyotyping, t(11,14) and del 13 are associated with standard risk and a survival of 6-7 years.

Presence of any aneuploidy in karyotyping is associated with a high risk. Any other chromosomal anomaly than mentioned above is associated with high risk. 2-3 year survival.

The ISS, when used along with the cytogenetic changes, forms the basis of the Revised ISS for staging.

Del 13 was previously thought to predict poor outcome, but now is not considered so due to the advent of newer agents.

questions.text: A patient presented with fever and bilateral temporal lobe inflammation. What is your diagnosis?

questions.text: Large, Irregular, Friable deposits on the heart valves are seen in?
questions.solution: Vegetations in infective endocarditis are large and friable. The vegetations in acute rheumatic fever are small and tend to occur along the line of closure of valves. The vegetations of Libmann Sachs are 1-3 mm warty deposits seen on either surface of any valves.
